About this document

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

The Smart Plan Suite (SPS) Containerized Network Function (CNF) Operation, Administration, and Maintenance Guide describes the Operations and Maintenance (OAM) procedures for CNF deployments of the SPS.

Intended audience

The intended audience of this document includes:
  • Service provisioners who provision the SPS data.
  • Service administrators who monitor the SPS.
  • Field support personnel who install the SPS and upgrade it to later versions.

Conventions used

Table 1 describes the conventions.

Table 1. Conventions
Appearance Description
emphasis Text that is emphasized.
graphic user interface text Text that is displayed in a graphical user interface.
user input Text that the user types as input to a system.
system output A value or command-line parameter that the user provides.
variable A value or command-line parameter that the user provides.
[ ] Text or value that is optional.

{ value1 │value2 }

{ variable1 │8.7 variable2 }

 A choice of values or variables from which one value or variable is used.

Related information

The following table lists other documentation resources that may be of use when working with the SPS.
Table 2. Nokia Smart Plan Suite 20.6 Documentation
Title Document Number
Overview Guide 9YZ-09018-UG00-PCZZA
Installation Guide 9YZ-09018-IN00-RJZZA
Operation, Administration, and Maintenance (OAM) Guide 9YZ-09018-MT00-REZZA

Charging User Guide 9YZ-09018-UG01-PCZZA
Subscriber Manager Guide 9YZ-09018-UG05-PCZZA
Notification Service (NS) User Guide 9YZ-09018-UG06-PCZZA
Global Configuration Guide 9YZ-09018-CN02-TCZZA

Web SSO configuration

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

This chapter describes the procedures required to configure and manage Web SSO on the SPS.

User administration with Web SSO

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

The maintenance of GUI users, passwords, and role mapping are performed using the Web SSO administration GUI. These tasks are performed by the administrator of the Web SSO GUI. The user administration on the SM GUI is replaced by the Web SSO GUI, wherein the user logs in again as a Web SSO administrator to perform actions other than changing their own password.
Note: Generally, an SM user who is not an administrator only needs to log in to the SM as usual and the SM redirects the user as required.

Creating a new or onboarding a new user

The Web SSO administrator creates new users using the following methods:
  • The administrator creates a new user using the given attributes:
    • Blank email address:
      • In the case that the email client is not configured, mark the "Email Verified" field as ON and make sure the "Required User Actions" is empty to enable user to log in.
    • Temporary password, which is further communicated to the user separately.
    • Required User Actions, set as Verify Email (Only if email client is configured).
    • Assigned a single SPS user role.
  • When a user logs in for the first time to the GUI:
    • Upon successful login, the user is forced to change own password.
    • If the Administrator did not enter the email ID when creating the new user, the user is redirected to the account settings screen where adding the email address is a mandatory entry.
    • The user logs in again to the GUI and after entering their credentials, the user is informed that email address is required to be verified and an email has been sent to the user email address with a link to validate.
    • The user receives the email, clicks the link, and logs in directly without entering any username or password.
    Note: This flow can be bypassed if the Web SSO administrator creates the new user with a profile with the email verified as ON and the Required User Actions set as empty.
    Note: The correct "email host" and a "from email id" should be configured to enable Web SSO to actually send an email to the user's email id. That configuration is done from: Spsauth → Realm Settings → Email in the Admin Console. The email host that is given should have an email client running on it.

Forgot or change user password

When the initial GUI is loaded and redirected to the Web SSO login screen, a forgot password link is provided to invoke the Web SSO features to administer the individual password of a user and for changing the password, a link is added to the SM GUI, which in turn invokes the Web SSO features.

GUI elements

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Log in and log out of the Web SSO GUI

To log into the Web SSO GUI as an administrator, open the web browser and enter https:// <smhostserver>:8666/auth/ in the address bar. Then, enter the username and password to access the Web SSO server GUI.

Note: The above mentioned username and password credentials are stored in system parameters, so they need to be in sync if SM login is to interact correctly with the WebSSO server. The following command can be used to view and change the credentials used by SM to communicate with the WebSSO server:
TPA_systemProp | grep CKEY
CKEY Admin User
CKEY Admin Password
Note: Generally, an SM user who is not an administrator only needs to log in to the SM as usual and the SM redirects the user as required.

Launch pad

Once a user logs into the Web SSO server GUI, the Launch Pad is displayed that provides various options. You can select the desired category under which all the entities belonging to that particular category are available.
Table 3. Categories available on the Web SSO server GUI
Category Description
Administration Console Allows you to centrally manage all aspects of the Web SSO server by redirecting to the Admin Console of the Web SSO server.
Documentation Allows you to access the documentation related to Web SSO server information, such as server installation and configuration guide, server administration guide, and Javadocs amongst many others.
Keycloak Project Allows you to learn Web SSO server basics, such as adding authentication to Web SSO server applications and securing services.
Mailing List Allows you to manage or subscribe to the Web SSO user mailing list.
Report an issue Allows you to resolve any known Web SSO server issues by redirecting to the known issues list and their related workarounds.

Admin Console administrative tasks

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

As the administrator, the bulk of your administrative tasks are done through the Web SSO Admin Console. The correct URL must be used. You can go to the console URL directly at https://<smhostserver>:8666/auth/admin/ and enter the user credentials you created in the add-user-keycloak script in the bin directory. This would further redirect you to the Web SSO Admin Console.
Note: : If the master realm user forgets their password, you can use the add-user-keycloak script to create a new administrator of the master realm.

As the administrator, the right-most drop-down menu on the admin console allows you to view your user account or logout from your current session. To enquire about a certain feature, button, or field within the Web SSO Admin Console, simply hover your mouse over any question mark ? icon, which pops up the tool-tip text to describe the area of the console you are interested in.

This section allows you to select the sps-auth realm, configure realm settings, clients, client scopes, roles, identity providers, user federation, and authentication using the Web SSO Admin Console.
Note: When a Geo-redundant pair of Service Managers (SMs) are installed and changes are done on the KeyCloak for any of these sites, you must clear the caches (realm, user, and key cache) on the other site to reflect the same changes. The only time that you do not need to do this is the creation and deletion of users, roles and user-role mapping which gets reflected without the need to clear the cache. The changes may include creation, deletion and modification on password policies, user attributes, clients, events etc. To clear the caches, do the following:
  1. Select the realm on which the changes were made.
  2. Go to "Realm Settings" -> "Cache”.
  3. Click the "Clear" button for all three caches (Realm Cache, User Cache, and Keys Cache).

Realm Settings

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

Realm Selection on the upper-left drop-down menu allows you to select the realm that you want to manage. The sps-auth realm is the only realm used in SPS and it is automatically created with SSL automatically configured on it by the SPS installation scripts.

Realm

A predefined realm is created when you boot the Web SSO server for the first time. This initial realm is referred to as the master realm or the head of all realms. The administrators of the master realm have the permissions to view and manage any other realm created on the server instance. When you define your initial administrator account, you create an account in the master realm. Your initial login to the Web SSO Admin Console is initiated through the master realm.

The realm has a dedicated admin console that can be accessed from the URL: /auth/admin/<realm-name>/console. The users within that realm can be granted realm management permissions by assigning specific user role mappings.
Note: : Do not use the master realm to manage the users and applications in your organization. You should preserve the master realm only for super administrator tasks, such as creating or managing realms in your system.

The SPS installation scripts create a realm called "sps-auth" along with associated client configurations for communicating with the local SM application.

SSL mode

The realm has an SSL mode associated with it, which defines the SSL or HTTPS requirements for interacting with the realm. The web browsers and applications that interact with the realm must comply with the SSL or HTTPS requirements defined by the SSL mode. SSL is configured by default during installation.

Accessing the SM GUI

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

Set up access to the SM GUI from the Web SSO Admin Console.

Setting up access to the SM GUI from the Web SSO Admin Console

As the administrator, choose “Sps-auth” from Realm Selection in the upper left of the screen then choose “Clients→Settings”. Configure the following to allow you to access the SM GUI:
  • Root URL
  • Base URL
  • Valid Redirect URIs: This is the URL that will be used to access the SM GUI. It can contain an IP address or a hostname, but not both. If the user accesses the SM GUI via another alias, an error message will pop up and a redirect will occur to the configured URL, so this should be set to the most commonly used URL. For example: https://<smhostserver>:8443/servicemanager/*
  • Admin URL

    This should be the same as the root URL except port 8666 and path /auth are present in the URL. For example: https://<smhostserver>:8666/auth

  • Web Origins:

    '*' is the most permissive value. Other values can be used. See the Online help.

Cache Invalidation

If there is switch over between instances of IOHO pods, any cached configuration created on one IOHO pod would not be reflected on the other instance. It is important for the user to clear the user,realm and key caches to get the latest updated configuration after switch over.

Events

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

The Web SSO server provides a defined set of auditing capabilities wherein every logic action is recorded and stored in the database, and reviewed in the Web SSO Admin Console. There is an event listener Service Provider Interface (SPI) which enables the plugins to listen to the events and perform some action, whereas built-in listeners include a simple log file and is enabled to send an email when an event occurs.

Event listener

Event listeners listen for events and perform an action based on that event. The Web SSO server has the following two built-in listeners:
  • Logging Event Listener, which writes to a log file whenever an error event occurs. This event listener is enabled by default. This event listener proves very useful to track the logging for any unauthorized access wherein a user tries to guess the passwords to get into the system. You can parse the log file for LOGIN_ERROR and extract the IP address of the machine from which unauthorized access was attempted.
  • Email Event Listener, which sends an email to the user account when an event occurs. This event listener only supports the following events:
    • Login error
    • Update password
    • Update TOTP
    • Remove TOTP

Login Events

Login events occur under one of the following conditions:
  • When a user logs in successfully to Web SSO server session.
  • When a user enters a wrong password to access the Web SSO server.
  • When a user account is updated on the Web SSO server.

Every single event that happens to a user can be recorded and viewed. By default, no events are stored or viewed in the Web SSO Admin Console. Only error events are logged to the console and server log file.

The login events can be viewed in the Login Events tab under the Events option. Login events are used to track the last login of a user, which is shown every time a user logs into the SM. The last login details of a user are saved for 6 months (182 days).
Table 4. Login Event parameters
Parameter name Description
Time This parameter indicates the time at which a particular event has been logged.
Event Type This parameter indicates whether the event type is LOGIN depending on the following information:
  • When a user has logged in.
  • When a user has registered.
  • When a user has logged out of the current session.
  • An application or client has exchanged a code for a token
  • An application or client has refreshed a token.
Details This parameter gives information about the client name, user account, IP address with other information like authentication method or type related to the logged event.

Admin Events

The Web SSO server can record any action performed by the admin user for auditing purposes. The Web SSO Admin Console performs administrative functions by invoking on the Web SSO REST interface and audits these REST invocations. The resulting events can then be viewed in the Admin Events tab under the Events option.
Table 5. Admin Events parameters
Parameter name Description
Time This parameter indicates the time at which a particular event has been logged.
Operation Type
Resource Type
Resource Path
Details If the Details column has a Representation box, then you can click on that to view the JSON that was sent with that operation.
Note: You can also filter for the events you are interested in by clicking the Filter button.

Configuration

Given that no events are stored or viewed in the Web SSO Admin Console, you need to enable storage on the Web SSO server. Go to the Events option from the left-most drop-down menu and then select the Config tab under the Events option.

Table 6. Config parameters
Parameter name Description
Events Config
Event Listeners This parameter allows you to select the event listener you wish to enable. For more information, see the "Event listener" section.
Login Event Settings
Save Events This parameter, when enabled, allows you to start storing events on the Web SSO server.
Saved Types This parameter allows you to specify which event types you want to store in the event store.
Clear events This parameter allows you to delete all the events in the database.
Expiration This parameter allows you to specify the duration for which the events can be stored in the database.
Admin Event Settings
Save Events This parameter allows you to enable the auditing of admin actions. For more information on admin events, see the “Admin Events” section.

Export and Import

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview of export and import using Web SSO Admin Console

The Web SSO Admin Console allows to import and export most of the resources in the Web SSO server database. However, the Web SSO Admin Console does not support the export of users.
Note: The attributes containing secret or private information are masked in the export file.
The files created during a startup export can also be used to import from the admin user interface, which enables you to export from one realm and import to another realm. Alternatively, you may export from one server and import to another.
Note: The Web SSO Admin Console exports or imports allows just one realm per file.

The Web SSO Admin Console import operation allows you to overwrite resources depending on your selection.

The Web SSO Admin Console export operation allows you to export clients, groups, and roles. If there is a great number of any specific assets in your realm, then this operation may take more time than usual to complete the entire process. During the transition of the export operation, the Web SSO server may not be responsive to user requests.

User Federation configuration

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview of User Federation in the Web SSO Admin Console

The SPS supports Web SSO (KeyCloak) functionality for LDAP and Active Directory. When a user logs in, KeyCloak will look into its own internal user store to find the user. If it cannot find it there, it will iterate over every User Storage provider you have configured for the realm until it finds a match. Data from the external store is mapped into a common user model that is consumed by the KeyCloak runtime.

In the Web SSO Admin Console you can navigate to Users > Lookup > View all users and select the one of interest to see the status of that user. The attribute Federation Link indicates whether the user is from LDAP. Other attributes, like User Temporarily Locked and Email Verified can be modified here if the user has problems with login.

User Federation configuration and settings

From the Web SSO Admin Console, navigate to the User Federation screen from a left-sidebar link, and choose “Add Provider”, then select LDAP as the type. “User Federation LDAP settings” is an example configuration for integration with the LDAP server. Details will vary depending on how the server is configured.
Note: All of the below configuration only needs to be done once on the active IOHO of one side of an SM pair. The configuration database is replicated so it takes effect on both sites.
Table 7. User Federation LDAP settings
Name Value Note
Priority 1 1 is highest. Keycloak internally defined users are higher than any externally defined users
Import users ON keycloak will import the user on first access and synchronize with it periodically
Sync Registrations OFF SPS will not write to this LDAP store
Vendor Other For ActiveDirectory integration, choose Active Directory here
Edit Mode READ_ONLY this is the only mode tested
Username LDAP attribute cn The ldap attribute mapped to SM login name
RDN LDAP attribute cn The ldap attribute used to lookup this unique user
UUID LDAP attribute cn The ldap attribute that uniquely identifies this user
User Object Class inetOrgPerson The schema used for describing user records in the LDAP store
Connection URL ldap://1.1.1.1:10389 —
Users DN ou=people,dc=internal,dc= users,dc=root The directory hierarchy where users are located in LDAP store
Bind Type simple how to authenticate to the LDAP server
Bind DN cn=Directory Manager privileged user name for authenticating to LDAP server
Bind Credential *** privileged user password
Search Scope One Level —
Validate Password Policy OFF Related to update which is not currently supported for the SPS integration
Connection Pooling ON —
Connection Timeout 10000 —
Read Timeout 10000 —
Pagination ON —

User Federation Mappers for users

You can create mappers for LDAP attributes, to convert them when KeyCloak imports user information. Do not change the existing OOB mappers as these result in LDAP attributes being injected into the KeyCloak token. The username displayed on the GUI is of the most significance.
  • last name
  • email
  • modify date
  • first name
  • username
  • creation date

User Federation Mappers for roles

There are two options for user-to-role mapping.

  • LDAP groups.

    With LDAP groups, the user-to-role mapping is defined entirely in LDAP. See “User Federation > ldap > LDAP Mappers: Create” for configuration details.

  • Default Role

    With default-role, there is no mapping in LDAP, so a single role is assigned by KeyCloak to any users authenticated from a particular LDAP store. If it is not possible to configure ldap groups, users can authenticate and be given a default role using the KeyCloak static configuration. To do this navigate to: User Federation > myldap > LDAP Mappers: Create and configure:
    • Name: defaultRole
    • Mapper Type: hardcoded-ldap-role-mapper
    • Role: administrator (or other desired common role)

If a default role is configured in KeyCloak, nothing else needs to be done in the LDAP server.

LDAP groups

A mapper is created for importing roles from LDAP, which are stored there as groups. The import is done from KeyCloak by querying LDAP for the groups to which a given user belongs. Typically groups in LDAP are defined as groupOfNames or groupOfUniqueNames, where the group object contains multiple attributes, one for each member. This configuration tells KeyCloak how to query the group and extract the username for membership. The group name becomes the role name in KeyCloak. For example: if you create a group “smprovisioners” in LDAP with a member ”smuser1”. Then when smuser1 logs into SM, the role smprovisioners will be assigned to that user. This role must also be setup in SM with the appropriate permissions.

You need to create a group for each SM role. The group name needs to be the SM role name. The groups should be located in the directory tree to match the configuration of the mapper in KeyCloak. For example: "ou=groups,dc=internal,dc=users,dc=root".
Note: Locally defined users such as the OOB smadmin user continue to work as before, after LDAP integration is enabled. Keycloak checks for locally-defined users before searching LDAP
Table 8. User Federation > ldap > LDAP Mappers: Create
Name Value Note
Name smroles —
Mapper Type role-ldap-mapper —
LDAP Roles DN ou=groups,dc=internal,dc= users,dc=root Where to find groups in LDAP
RoleName LDAP Attribute cn What attribute to use for the role name
Role Object Classes groupOfUniqueNames What schema is used to define the group (could also be groupOfNames)
Membership LDAP Attribute uniqueMember What attribute in the group object identifies a member
Membership Attribute Type DN How to interpret the member data value, here we say it contains a fully qualified Distinguished Name)
Membership User LDAP Attribute cn Unused
Mode READ_ONLY —
User Roles Retrieve Strategy LOAD_ROLES_BY_ MEMBER_ATTRIBUTE use the group object itself and process the membership list
Member-Of LDAP Attribute memberOf Unused
Use Realm Roles Mapping ON —

Client Mappers

Create a hard-coded attribute to inform the GUI that user information is read only and cannot be modified by SM. This is communicated to the GUI through the userInfo data that the GUI fetches at login time, from the KeyCloak server. Navigate to: Clients > "spssm" > mappers (tab) > Create and configure the following:
  • name: readonly
  • Mapper Type: hardcoded claim
  • Token Claim Name: readonly
  • Claim value: true
  • Claim JSON Type: Boolean
  • Add to ID token: OFF
  • Add to access token: OFF
  • Add to userinfo: ON

KeyCloak configuration for secure access

KeyCloak be configured to access LDAP via the secure protocol (ldaps). To do this, KeyCloak needs to trust the LDAP server certificate. This can be done by importing the ldap server certificate into KeyCloak's client keystore. This currently requires manual configuration for which an example is shown below for configuring KeyCloak to connect with a samba-based AD server via ldaps on port 636:

On an AD server:
# cd /usr/local/samba/private/tls
# cat cert.pem ca.pem > adclient.chain.pem
# openssl pkcs12 -export -inkey key.pem -in chain.pem -out adclient.p12
password: 123456
# scp adclient.p12 chain.pem keycloakserver:/opt/keycloak/security/ssl
(note, you only need adclient.chain.pem for verifying the connection with
openssl below)
On each KeyCloak server (IOHO) of the pair in the SPS site:
# cd /opt/keycloak/security/ssl
# keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore adclient.p12 -srcstoretype pkcs12
-destkeystore client_keystore.jks
dest password: keycloak
src password: 123456
To test the connection from KeyCloak server to ldap:
# openssl s_client -msg -connect <adserverhostname>:636 -CAfile chain.pem
... Verify return code: 0 (ok)
Note: The host name that you configure in KeyCloak needs to match the hostname in the certificate and that hostname must be able to be looked-up from the KeyCloak side, which may mean adding it to KeyCloak server's /etc/host file if it is not a DNS-registered hostname.

Measurement

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

This section describes the list of measurements and the collection mechanism used for the SPS.

Measurements

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

SPS collects a broad range of measurements to provide a rich set of data for understanding the load and behavior of the system and its network integration. Network operators can leverage these metrics to monitor the system’s behavior, as well as for engineering analysis of the system’s processing and capacity. The metrics are available to examine on the SPS itself and can also be retrieved by external systems for offboard analysis.

Deployment of the optional SPS telemetry package provides further options for measurement collection, storage, and retrieval.

The following topics will be covered in this section:
  • Measurement structure and optional labels
  • Measurement collection (SPS telemetry package)
  • Storage and retrieval of measurements in 3GP XML files (SPS telemetry package)

SPS measurement pegging is performed by Prometheus, a widely used third-party metrics and monitoring software package that is integrated in the Nokia Common Software Foundation (CSF).

The following Prometheus components are used in SPS for platform metrics:

  • Push gateway: configured on both AdminCLI pods at port 9091, for supporting short-lived jobs.

    The Prometheus push gateway exists to allow ephemeral and batch jobs to expose their metrics to Prometheus. These kinds of jobs may not exist long enough to be scraped, so they can instead push their metrics to a push gateway. The push gateway then exposes these metrics to Prometheus. See https://github.com/prometheus/pushgateway/blob/master/README.md for more information.

Optionally, if the SPS telemetry package is deployed, SPS measurement collection can also be performed by Prometheus.

The following Prometheus components are optionally used in SPS for platform metrics:

  • Grafana: to allow for data visualization with multiple modes of graphing and dashboarding support
  • Alertmanager: to handle alerts
  • Gen3GPPXML: generates 3GPP XML file according to the customized metric set, the metric value is retrieved from the Prometheus server through its REST API

The SPS measurements system includes the popular and powerful Grafana third-party platform for querying and visualizing the SPS metrics stored in Prometheus. Grafana includes built-in Prometheus support with features that include a query editor with metric name lookup and templating queries for generic dashboards. See “Getting started with Grafana technology” for a high level description of getting started with Grafana in SPS.

If the optional SPS telemetry package is deployed, SPS is also capable of generating alarms when a given metric has exceeded a configured threshold. The configuration data controls which metrics, at what thresholds, have what alert severities. See “Alarms when measurements cross a threshold” for a high level description of generating alarms when a given metric has exceeded a configured threshold in SPS.

Measurement Structure and Optional Labels

SPS measurements are structured with an object model that consolidates a rich set of information into a small number of measurements. This is achieved by virtue of adding labels to the measurements that provide several more levels of detail. For example, there is a single Diameter Inbound Count measurement, but there are labels for recording the Application (Gx, Gy, Sy, etc.), the Command (CCR, AAR, RAR, etc.), the RequestType (Initial Request, Update Request, etc.), Result code (Diameter Success, Diameter Limited Success, etc.), as well as information about the peer host and realm.

With this wealth of data, users can then examine the SPS measurements from a variety of dimensions to gain a detailed understanding of the system traffic and behavior. Questions such as the following can be answered:
  • How many Diameter requests succeeded or failed?
  • How many CCR requests failed?
  • How many CCR requests failed from a given Diameter realm?

In addition, some measurements are defined with a Custom Label. This provides an open-ended way of recording additional data in AVPs, with multiple AVPs able to be stored as a single Custom Label.

Measurement collection (SPS telemetry package)

If using the optional SPS telemetry package, metrics are gathered onto the central AdminCLI pods in each SPS, where the Prometheus server and database are located. Both AdminCLI pods run the Prometheus server and both actively collect measurement data from the clients and store the data in their own local databases, such that all measurements data continues to be available following an AdminCLI switchover. A Prometheus client runs on all the nodes that are recording metrics to be collected by the Prometheus server on the AdminCLI.

Prometheus provides a multi-dimensional data model with time series data identified by metric name and key/value pairs. A flexible query language is supported for retrieving data from the database. Prometheus GUI queries should be executed on the AdminCLI standby pod.

The Prometheus GUI URL can be configured using the helm charts on installation. For more information, see the SPS CNF Installation Guide.

For more details about Prometheus, its configuration, tools, and features, please refer to information found on the internet.

Storage and Retrieval of Measurements in 3GPP XML files (SPS telemetry package)

Each SPS SM and ME system periodically (for example, every 5 minutes) retrieves measurements data from Prometheus and records it into 3GPP XML files that are then made available for northbound OSS systems to retrieve by SFTP. This is achieved via the Gen3GPPPXML script that is called from the /usr/local/etc/Gen3GPPXML.json file.

See the SPS Installation Guide for information about configuring the key parameter values required for the Gen3GPPXML file.

Gen3GPPXML creates measurements files on the AdminCLI pods and stores them in the /appdata directory with a path that depends on the version of NetAct being used. (See the SPS Installation Guide for information about the correct path to the Gen3GPPXML file by version of NetAct.) These files are available to be retrieved and processed by northbound OSS systems, including Nokia NetAct.

The files are named as follows:
<date>.<starttime>-<endtime>_<sitename>-<nodename>
where:
<date> = YYYYMMDD
<starttime> = HHMMZ (where Z is a timezone for example, -0700)
<endtime> = HHMMZ (where Z is a timezone for example, -0700)
<sitename> = The name given to the SPS site.
<nodename> = The node name or container name in SPS that recorded the
measurement.

For example: A20190131.1800+0000-1805+0000_sps-me-1-diameterapp-13

Gen3GPPXML generates one XML file for one node by default. The node name is appended to the filename. If the postFix is set with an non-empty value all the measurement data for all the nodes is written into one XML file, then “gen3gppxmlDefaultPostFix” is appended to the filename; for example:

A20181226.1849+0000-1850+0000_gen3gppxmlDefaultPostFix

Inside the XML file, there are indicators for the end time of the collection interval and the duration of that interval, in seconds. There may be multiple measurements in each group, with their names and measurement values clearly indicated.

There is a separate XML entry for each combination of metric values recorded during this interval. If a “Last Interval” type metric value (for example, diameter_inbound_average_latency_last_interval) has not changed during the last interval, it will not appear in the XML file. Metric values for other metrics are continually recorded in the XML file.

The following shows an example format within the XML files. Each metric has many labels but each metric has a single value and in the XML file.
<granPeriod duration="PT300S" endTime="2019-02-05T06:55:00+00:00" />
<repPeriod duration="PT300S" />
<measType p="1">diameter_inbound_sum</measType>
<measType p="2">diameter_inbound_count</measType>
<measType p="3">diameter_inbound_rate</measType>
<measType p="4">diameter_inbound_average_latency_overall</measType>
<measType p="5">diameter_inbound_average_latency_last_interval</measType>
<measValue measObjLdn="app=1, dia=1, host=ME-2-diameterapp-0,
Application=Gx, Command=CCR, RequestType=INITIAL_REQUEST (1),
Result=DIAMETER_SUCCESS, OriginHost=NA, IngressPeerOriginHost=NA,
CustomLabel={}">
<r p="1">1390744</r>
<r p="2">109246</r>
<r p="3">2.7228070175438592</r>
<r p="4">12.73076500430395</r>
<r p="5">11.13917525773196</r>
</measValue>
Note: The XML file format was slightly different prior to the SPS 19.3 release. For backward compatibility until the connected OSS systems are updated to also support this newer format, SPS can be configured to create XML files in the older format. This is for transition purposes only. The following is an example measurement from prior (compatibility mode) 3GPPXML file format:
<measData>
manageElement localDn="UHN3tli1smme0001 diameterapp 0" userLabel=
"UHN3tli1smme0001 diameterapp 0"
<measInfo>
<granPeriod duration="PT300S" endTime="2019-02-05T06:55:00+00:00" />
<repPeriod duration="PT300S" />
<measTypes>diameter_inbound_sum diameter_inbound_count diameter_
inbound_rate diameter_inbound_average_latency_ overall diameter_
inbound_average_latency_last_interval</measTypes>
<measValue measObjLdn="host=ME2-diameterapp-1, dia=1, a pp=1,
Application=Gx, Command=CCR, CustomLabel={}, Ingr essPeerOriginHost=NA,
IngressPeerOriginRealm=NA, Origin Host=NA, OriginRealm=NA, RequestType=
INITIAL_REQUEST (1 ), Result=DIAMETER_SUCCESS, instance=
ME2-diameterapp-1: 9111, job=application_metrics">
<measResults>38676622 1903705 9.991666666666667 20.31
6499667753146 14.646371976647206</measResults>
</measValue>
<measInfo>
To use the older format, you must configure the following key to be “horizontal” at installation time.
cpro/gen3gppxml/orientation horizontal

See the SPS-Installation Guide for more information about configuring this parameter key.

Metrics configuration with SPS telemetry package

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

The SPS measurements system can be configured to meet the needs of a given operator deployment, including which labels are muted, the collection/gathering interval, and various other parameters. The following sections describe configuration for measurement collection:
  • Metrics configuration files
  • Getting started with Grafana technology
  • Muting of Selected Labels
  • Alarms when measurements cross a threshold

Metrics configuration files

Prometheus stores it metrics into a database. Every 5 minutes, Gen3GPPXML retrieves some measurements and writes them into XML files in the /appdata/cpro/prometheus directory.

For the Prometheus server, a configuration file exists as cpro/server/config.file which is a key that stores all of the configuration data of Prometheus. The prometheus.yml contains data which contains data based on the values stored in the Prometheus keys; for example: the cpro/server/ config.file contains the /etc/prometheus/prometheus.yml. See the key parameters in the VNF Extension file in the SPS Installation Guide for information about configuring the values, for example:
  • storage_retention—the length of time to retain samples in the database The default storage_retention time is 15 days. You must contact Nokia Support to change this parameter after installation.
  • scrape_interval—the duration (in seconds) after which targets are scraped The default value is 60 seconds (1 minute) and stored on the AdminCLI in /appdata/cpro/ prometheus. You must contact Nokia Support to change this parameter after installation.
Note:

Do not change the permissions for any file or folder related to Prometheus. There is a risk that metrics generation is stopped if you change the permissions for any file or folder related to Prometheus.

If any nodes that are generating metrics undergoes an application server restart for any reason, the metrics counter is reset to 0. System metrics are not reset in the case of application server restart but do continue from previous values.

Getting started with Grafana technology

Before trying to use Grafana technology, ensure the parameter keys for the Grafana software have been configured. See the VNF Extension file in the SPS Installation Guide for more information.
Note: Grafana software and its configuration does not support a switch-over. Each instance of Grafana software works independently on each AdminCLI and must be configured (including: dashboard, users, and other settings) on both AdminCLI pods, active and standby.

To work in the Grafana GUI from SPS, you must create the users. As the “admin” user of the Grafana technology:

Log in to the Grafana GUI using the URL configured on helm installation of the Grafana container. For more information regarding helm deployment of the Grafana container, see the SPS CNF Installation Guide.

Enter the following credentials when prompted:

User name: admin

Password: admin

When you log in for the first time you will be asked to change your password. Nokia strongly encourages you to follow the Grafana technology best practices and change the default administrator password. The Grafana GUI is available after a successful deployment at the user configurable Grafana GUI URL.

Before you create your first dashboard you need to ensure that your data source has been configured correctly at:
https://<grafana_gui_url>/datasources
The data source should be set to Prometheus and Port 9090. Perform the following steps to configure the Grafana datasource with port 9090:
  1. Log in to the Grafana GUI at: https://<grafana_gui_url>/
  2. In the Configuration tab, select Data Sources and then select Prometheus Datasource.
  3. Update the HTTP URL field with port 9090.
  4. Save the configuration, using the Save & Test button.

Create your dashboard. See the screencasts tutorial for instruction on creating dashboards at:

http://docs.grafana.org/tutorials/screencasts

Muting of Selected Labels

In some network environments, recording detailed information for all labels will result in a very large volume of data and metrics combinations, which may be too much for the engineering of the system or for the northbound OSS systems to consume as they retrieve measurement files from SPS. To address this, SPS supports a capability for “muting” selected measurements labels. When a label is muted, its value is recorded as “NA” (not available). In this case, there is only a single value for that label, and thus, reducing the combinatorics that may be contributing to a very large volume of measurement data.

Application metric labels can be muted or un-muted for the SM and ME using the following application preferences. The measurements tables in later sections specify which labels can be muted for a given measurement.
Table 9. Muting metric labels
Application Preference Name Type Metric Name Default Value
Mute Diameter metric labels (true/false) Boolean Diameter true
Mute HTTP_3GPP metric labels (true/false) Boolean http_3gpp true
Mute HTTP metric labels (true/false) Boolean HTTP true
Mute LDAP metric labels (true/false) Boolean LDAP false
Mute Rating metric labels (true/false) Boolean Rating true
Mute Site Routing metric labels Boolean Site Routing true

Alarms when measurements cross a threshold

The SPS generates alarms when a pre-configured metric exceeds a configured threshold.

Standard metrics alarms are created from Prometheus alerts. See the SPS Installation Guide for more information about configuring the alert rule key in the VNF Extension files.

Viewing alert details in Prometheus

Prometheus provides a separate GUI for Alert Manager which is accessible at the Prometheus Alert Manager GUI URL, which is configured on helm installation. For more information regarding helm deployment of the Prometheus Alert Manager GUI, see the SPS CNF Installation Guide.

The Alert Manager handles alerts sent by client applications, in SPS it is the Prometheus server. It takes care of deduplicating, grouping, and routing them to the correct receiver such as: email, PagerDuty, or OpsGenie. It also takes care of the silencing and inhibiting of alerts. For more details, refer to Alert Manager official site at:
https://prometheus.io/docs/alerting/alertmanager

SPS measurements

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

SPS collects measurements for the following areas:
  • Diameter (Base) metrics
  • Diameter supplemental metrics
  • Device notification metrics
  • LDAP metrics
  • Surepay LDAP metrics
  • HTTP metrics
  • HTTP_3GPP metrics for 5G
  • Site Routing metrics
  • Rules metrics
  • Overload Metrics
  • Rating metrics
  • PCRF and PCF metrics
  • Entity count metrics
  • CDR metrics
  • Notification server metrics
  • NRF metrics
Note: Some of the metrics in the following tables are noted as being calculated by applying Prometheus rules on other collected metrics, demarcated by the phrase "(SPS telemetry package)". These are only available if the SPS Telemetry package is deployed, or if the operator implements these rules in their own Prometheus server. Nokia can provide these rules upon request.
Note:
For average_latency_last_interval, this is the change in latency over a configurable period of time, which can be increasing as well as decreasing. For example, using the diameter_inbound_sum and diameter_inbound_count metrics, the average_latency_last_ interval is calculated as follows:
rate(diameter_outbound_sum[<period>]) / rate(diameter_outbound_count[<period>])

Where for example, in the last <period> (let’s say period of 5 minutes), the first value of diameter_inbound_sum is S1, and the last value of diameter_inbound_sum is S5. Then: "rate(diameter_inbound_sum[])" is equal to "(S5 - S1) / 300s" and in the last , the first value of "diameter_inbound_count" is C1, and the last value of "diameter_inbound_count" is C5. Then: "rate(diameter_inbound_count[5 minutes])" is equal to "(C5 - C1) / 300s" Then the average latency in the last 5 minutes is as follows:

((S5 - S1) / 300s) / ((C5 - C1) / 300s)

Note:

The value of any of the count since last interval metrics is an extrapolated value and never an exact value. This behavior is from the way that Prometheus does the calculation. This is calculated using the increase( ) function; for example, increase(diameter_inbound_ count[10m]) or increase(ldap_count[10m]), etc. The "Increase()" function uses a minimum of two data points over a time period and based on these two data points a change in count since last interval value is calculated. Prometheus does an approximation because it calculates count since last interval in a fail safe way that is resistant to failures such as scrape miss, node restarts, etc.

The recommended value for last interval (default 10 minutes), should be at least twice that of the granularity period gen3gppxml/default_gran_period) defined in Gen3GPPXML tool. This is to ensure that the Gen3GPPXML tool, would be able to take the snapshot of count since last interval metrics at least once. For example, if the granularity period configured is 300s (5 minutes), you should configure the last interval window in count since last interval metrics as 10 minutes. See the “Gen3gppxml section” in the SPS Installation Guide for more information about these parameters.

Note:
When an incoming 5G message arrives at an SPS ME over HTTP/2, it may be siterouted to another home SPS ME. For example, consider a case where an incoming N7 request that first lands on ME 1 is site-routed to ME 2, which is the home for the device (PGW > ME1 > ME2). The metrics for this example are established as follows:
  • On ME1, http_3gpp_inbound metrics are pegged along with the site_routing metric pegged with the “InProtocol” label indicating “http_3gpp” and the “Decision” label indicating “message sent to primary”.
  • From ME1 to ME2, the message is forwarded using the Diameter protocol.
  • On ME2, the diameter_inbound metrics are pegged to set the “DiameterApp” label to N7 (for this example) to distinguish this from standard 4G Diameter messages received. The site_routing metric is then pegged with the “InProtocol” label indicating ‘http_3gpp’ and the “Decision” label indicating “processed locally”.

Diameter (Base) metrics

The base Diameter measurements record the number of Diameter messages in and out of SPS, the specific type of messages, the result of the message processing, and who was the peer. There are a number of labels within these measurements that provide a rich set of detailed information for understanding the behavior of the SPS Diameter interactions. These metrics are recorded on the ME Diameter Application pods.

See the following for Diameter base metrics:
  • “Diameter inbound metrics” describes the Diameter inbound metrics.
  • “Diameter outbound metrics ” describes the Diameter outbound metrics.
  • “Diameter supplemental metrics” describes the Diameter inbound and outbound supplemental metrics.

Diameter Inbound (base)

Table 10. Diameter Inbound (base)
Metric Description
diameter_inbound_count Number of inbound Diameter messages accumulated since the start of this node.
diameter_inbound_rate (SPS telemetry package) Average rate of inbound Diameter messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
diameter_inbound_average_latency_last_interval (SPS telemetry package) Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
diameter_inbound_average_latency_overall (SPS telemetry package) Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
diameter_inbound_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages).
diameter_inbound_count_last_interval Number of inbound Diameter messages accumulated since last count interval.
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version.
DIA Always ‘1’ in this SPS version.
HOST SPS host name (e.g. container name).
DIAAPP

Diameter App. Possible values:

Gx, Gy, Sy, etc.
CMD

Diameter Command. Possible values:

RAR, CCR, AAR, etc.
REQ

Diameter Request Type. Possible values:

INITIAL_REQUEST (1), UPDATE_REQUEST (2), etc.
RESULT

Possible values shown in Table 4.

DIAMETER_SUCCESS, DIAMETER_LIMITED_SUCCESS, etc.
IRMHST Diameter ingress realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
ORMHST Diameter origin realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
CUSTOM Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available. For example, this could indicate that the Event Trigger was an UE_IP_ADDRESS_ALLOCATE (18)

Diameter Outbound (base)

Table 11. Diameter Outbound (base)
Metric Description
diameter_outbound_count Number of outbound Diameter messages accumulated since the start of this node.
diameter_outbound_rate (SPS telemetry package) Average rate of outbound Diameter messages (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
diameter_outbound_average_latency_last_interval (SPS telemetry package) Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
diameter_outbound_average_latency_overall (SPS telemetry package) Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
diameter_outbound_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
diameter_outbound_count_last_interval Number of outbound Diameter messages accumulated since last count interval
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
DIA Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HOST SPS host name (e.g. container name)
DIAAPP

Diameter App. Possible values:

Gx, Gy, Sy, etc.
CMD

Diameter Command. Possible values:

RAR, CCR, AAR, etc.
REQ

Diameter Request Type. Possible values:

INITIAL_REQUEST (1), UPDATE_REQUEST (2), etc.
RESULT

Possible values:

DIAMETER_SUCCESS, DIAMETER_LIMITED_SUCCESS, etc.
DRMHST Diameter destination realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
ERMHST Diameter egress realm and host. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
CUSTOM Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available. For example, this could indicate that the Event Trigger was an UE_IP_ADDRESS_ALLOCATE (18)

LDAP

Table 12. LDAP
Metric Description
ldap_count Number of LDAP query attempts accumulated since the start of this node
ldap_rate (SPS telemetry package) Average rate of LDAP query attempts (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
ldap_average_latency_last_interval (SPS telemetry package) Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
ldap_average_latency_overall (SPS telemetry package) Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
ldap_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
ldap_count_last_interval Number of LDAP query attempts accumulated since last count interval
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
LDAP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HOST SPS host name (e.g. container name)
RESULT

Whether the search was successful. Will be unmuted by default, but may be muted (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity. Possible values:

Success, Failure
CUSTOM Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.

HTTP

Table 13. HTTP
Metric Description
http_count Number of inbound HTTP requests accumulated since the start of this node
http_rate (SPS telemetry package) Average rate of inbound HTTP requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
http_average_latency_last_interval (SPS telemetry package) Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
http_average_latency_overall (SPS telemetry package) Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
http_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
http_count_last_interval Number of inbound HTTP requests accumulated since last count interval
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HTTP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HOST SPS host name (e.g. container name)
METHOD

HTTP method. Possible values:

GET, PUT, POST, DELETE
STATUS HTTP result status (per HTTP standards)
CROOT The context root of the HTTP URI address. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
SOURCE IP address of the source initiating this HTTP request. Will be muted by default (shown as NA) to reduce metrics verbosity.
CUSTOM Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.

NotificationServer

Table 14. NotificationServer
Metric Description
notificationserver_count Number of inbound notificationserver requests accumulated since the start of this node
notificationserver_rate Average rate of inbound notificationserver requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
notificationserver_average_latency_last_interval Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
notificationserver_average_latency_overall Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
notificationserver_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
notificationserver_count_last_interval Number of inbound/outbound notificationserver requests accumulated since last count interval
Labels (in XML)
NOTOPR OperationName : Always ‘pushNotification/process’ in this SPS version
REQ RequestType : Always ‘INBOUND/OUTBOUND’ in this SPS version
TEMPL TemplateName : SPS Notification Server's Template name (e.g. Template1)
CHANL Channel : Notification Channels (e.g. KAFKA, REST, SOAP, EMAIL, SMS and TCP etc)
STATUS Status : Notification INBOUND Status: (OK, SUCCESS, FAILURE, Bad Request), Notification OUTBOUND Status: (SUCCESS, FAILURE, RETRY)
CUSTOM CustomLabel : Notification custom level (e.g. for success - OK, SUCCESS and for failure: "Unable to process your request")
NOTSER for Notification service: Always ‘1’ in this SPS version

HTTP 3GPP (i.e. 5G) Inbound

Table 15. HTTP 3GPP (i.e. 5G) Inbound
Metric Description
http_3gpp_inbound_count Number of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since this node start
http_3gpp_inbound_rate (SPS telemetry package) Average rate of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests (per second) during this recent interval. (calculated sum/interval duration).
http_3gpp_inbound_average_latency_last_interval (SPS telemetry package) Average latency during this recent interval (calculated sum/count).
http_3gpp_inbound_average_latency_overall (SPS telemetry package) Average latency for all accumulated intervals (calculated sum/count).
http_3gpp_inbound_sum Sum of all latencies accumulated since the start of this node (to calculate averages)
http_3gpp_inbound_count_last_interval Number of inbound 5G HTTP/2 requests accumulated since last interval count
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HT3GPP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version

RESULT

Possible values:

SUCCESS etc.
STATUS HTTP result status (per HTTP standards)
CUSTOM Custom labels are optional AVPs and may be different for each measurement instance, providing additional system insights as available.

Site Routing

Table 17. Site Routing
Metric Description
site_routing Number of incoming messages processed by the SPS ME site routing function
site_routing_count_last_interval SITE ROUTING application metric counts generated as count per last interval
Labels (in XML)
APP Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
SITROU Always ‘1’ in this SPS version
HOST SPS host name (e.g. container name)
STATUS

The status/result of the site routing, which contributes to the Decision. Possible values:

Site routing succeeds

Primary site is OOS

Primary site is not reachable

Primary and secondary sites are OOS

Primary and secondary sites are not reachable

No site Id exists for the request

Requests with no site routing resolver

Site routing lookup failed

Site routing will not process the request
DECSN

Site routing decision. Possible values:Requests processed locally: Message sent to a local app for processing

Requests routed to primary: Message sent to the primary SPS ME for processing

Requests routed to secondary: Message sent to the secondary SPS ME for processing

Reject message: message is rejected due to an error in site routing, which could be the target site is OOS, not reachable, a site ID look up failed, or some other failure case.
MSGRF From whom this incoming message is received. The value of the origin host of the Diameter peer that sent this request message, which could be another SPS site or external GW.
PSITE The resolved primary Site ID (SPS ME) for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message
SSITE The resolved secondary Site ID (SPS ME) for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message
SITROL

The site role of this local SPS ME for the device/subscriber/etc. contained in this message. Possible values:

Primary site

Secondary site

Third site (local site is neither the primary nor secondary)
IPROTO Refers to the protocol
INST SPS instance generating metrics

RATGRP Rating group. The charging key for the Diameter Credit-Control service identifying a rating group (uniquely identified by the combination of Service-Context-Id and Rating-Group). All the services subject to the same rating type are part of the same rating group.

Possible values include:

DIAMETER_SUCCESS, DIAMETER_LIMITED_SUCCESS, etc.

AdminCLI

FAIL,

Possible values are:

NOTIFY_FAILURE (Notification failed at SM, since it could not be contacted),

SM_QUEUE_FULL_FAILURE (Notification could not be queued at SM since SM queue was full)

The Acknowledgement Status received from SM.

Possible value is:

ACK_RECEIVED

The Status of the processing performed at ME after Acknowledgement from SM is received at ME.

Possible values are:

SUCCESS (when SyncOp is successfuly reset in the database),

FAILED (when SyncOp reset fails ),

IGNORED (when SyncOp reset is not tried due to inconsistency of SyncOp values received from SM and present in ME database)

Logging

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

This chapter describes how to manage SPS logging functions.

Logs are written to stdout. They are processed/directed by fluentd. Users can search, filter, or browse the logs using standard tools including Elasticsearch and Kibana.

https://confluence.app.alcatel-lucent.com/display/plateng/CNOT+-+Notification+Server

Supported logs

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Log aggregation

Log aggregation is done by Fluentd (for both SM and ME separately) to aggregate logs on the AdminCLI pods. Fluentd is an open source data collector that allows the SPS to decouple data sources from backend systems using the unified logging layer.

Unified logging

The Unified API provides the logs in the same format for alarms and logs.

Note: The Unified logging APIs no longer allow for the consolidation of alarm messages in the AdminCLI pod's log file (SPSServer). However, SPSServer on every node logs alarm events into their own respective log files in a unified format.
The Unified logging format for all logs is as follows:
  • type: The type can be one of "log", "alarm", or "counter".
  • level: The following logging levels are supported:
    • 0=EMERG
    • 1=ALERT
    • 2=CRIT
    • 3=ERROR
    • 4=WARN
    • 5=NOTICE
    • 6=INFO
    • 7=DEBUG
  • process: Name and/or ID of the process producing the event.
  • service: Name of the service to which the event is related. For service in the SPS, this field is correlated with the existing TAG field that is used in the SYSLOG to differentiate logs coming from the different applications.
  • system: System name of the system in which the event occurred.
  • systemid: System identifier assigned to the system in which the event occurred.
  • timezone: Timezone of the local host's time.
  • message: The text of the log message.
  • process: Name of the program language method where the log is issued.
  • classname: Nome of the program language class where the log is issued.
  • stacktrace: A report of the active stack frames at a certain point in time during the execution of a program.
The following is an example of a log in the unified logging format:
{"host":"sps-ig-diameterapp-1","level":"INFO","log":{"classname":"com.
alcatel.tpapps.pcrf.common.DiameterPeerManager:671","message":"Finished
background OSI monitor.","stacktrace":"","threadname":
"InactiveOSIMonitorMBean-1"},"process":"remoteOSIMonitor","service":
"SPS","time":"2019-03-18T07:26:36.010Z","timezone":"America/Toronto",
"type":"log","system":"SPS_IG_19_3_R1_I126","systemid":
"CBAM-347708862db84371977879338f3a33c2"}

Log rotation

To prevent Java application and database log files from becoming too large, rotation can be configured for each log file. If a log's file size reaches the specified limit, it will be rotated. There is no log rotation for the CDR logs.
Note: The configuration of log rotation can lead to an increase in disk usage. The logs are kept in the log volumes of a container. You must take care of the dimensioning aspects of these files and provision the disk volumes accordingly. For more details about volume sizes and dimensioning aspects, refer to the section: "SPS cloud-platform resources and services" in the SPS Installation Guide.
Platform log rotation

Logs from all SPS node components (for example, I/Os) are forwarded to the active AdminCLI, and all of those logs are stored on each of the AdminCLI pods but accessible via the active AdminCLI in the /var/log/system/nokia_harmonized.log files. Log rotation for platform logs is configured at installation. See the "Log rotate" section in the SPS Installation Guide for information about configuring log rotation.

Application and Aerospike log rotation

The SPS applications and the Aerospike database run as third-party applications with their own runtime environment. Logs from all SPS applications and databases reside under the /opt/tpa/logs/ directory of any container that has either the Application or the Aerospike processes running. SPS specific Application and Aerospike log files found under /opt/tpa/logs directory on any container and all of those log files that are aggregated on both the AdminCLI pods are stored under the /var/log/sps directory on both the AdminCLI pods. That is, Application logs are dumped at both AdminCLI pods.

Log rotation for AdminCLI logs is configured at installation. See the "log rotate" section in the SPS Installation Guide for information about configuring log rotation.

Platform logs

The platform logs are placed into the /var/log/ directory on the active AdminCLI.

The /var/log/ha/ha.log platform log is supported. Roles, either ACTIVE or STANDBY, are logged for each of the HA node types. HA node types include IOHO, IOHD, and AdminCLI.

Log rotation is not applicable for the /var/log/ha/ha.log.

SPS Application logs

On AdminCLI pods, site log aggregation is done under the /var/log/sps directory of the AdminCLI. For application logs, the SPS sends INFO level and higher logs to the AdminCLI.

SPS specific Application and Aeropsike log files found under /opt/tpa/logs/ directory on any container and that are aggregated on to both AdminCLI pods are stored under the /var/log/sps/ directory on the AdminCLI pods. Each of the containers stores a copy of their local logs in the /opt/tpa/logs/ directory and the same is consolidated on to both the AdminCLI pods in the /var/log/sps directory, as follows:
  • /var/log/sps/TPA_system.log
    • Includes SPS ASR logs, Diameter, SM app logs, etc.
  • /var/log/sps/keycloak.log
    • For consolidation of keylcoak logs from both IOHO nodes in harmonized format on both AdminCLIs
  • /var/log/sps/SPSServer.log
  • /var/log/sps/Server.log
  • /var/log/sps/localization.log
  • /var/log/sps/Spotlight.log
  • /var/log/sps/ManagedElement.log
  • /var/log/sps/Provisioning.log
    • The SM provisioning log
  • /var/log/sps/SericeManager.log
    • SM logs
  • /var/log/sps/UserAccess.log
  • /var/log/sps/HLAPIServer.log
  • /var/log/sps/LDAPSearch.log
  • /var/log/sps/DiamaterInterceptor.log
  • /var/log/sps/DSCSecurity.log
  • /var/log/sps/aerospike_warning.log
    • Aerospike database-related logs
  • /var/log/sps/Cdr.log
    • CDR logs
  • /var/log/sps/watson.log
    • Watson shell logs
The ER logs are configured in tpaEventLogging.xml. If EDR log does not need to aggregate to the AdminCLI, the output log file can be confiugred to use a directory other than /opt/tpa/logs.
Note: Alarm logging is available in /opt/tpa/logs/SPSServer.log on the local node in Unified Format but is not consolidated in the AdminCLI pod. Alarm histroy is recorded in /var/log/calm/history.log and only shows the alarm history for clear alarms.
Note: HA service specific alarms are only available in /var/log/messages on the local node. Traps that trigger these alarms will not be sent either.

Operating or other system logs

The SPS occasionally writes messages to operating system log files or other application log files. An aggregated view of logs from all nodes in each site can be found within the /var/log/system/ directory on both the AdminCLIs.

The log rotation of operation system and other system logs is done on all nodes, not just AdminCLI pods. See the "Log rotate" section in the SPS Installation Guide for information about configuring log rotation.

User activity logs

The logging of user actions is enabled with Watson shell. Watson shell is a specialized login shell that is provisioned for any user. This shell is transparent to a user and automatically records to a log file all the command-line input and output of a user. Watson shell is the default for all users. Accounts can be configured to use or not to use Watson shell. This configuration is done on the Active AdminCLI pod with modify -user tool and propagated to all the other nodes. Only root users are allowed to disable Watson shell.

The output log file is stored in the /var/log/watson directory and is available on every container. The format of the log file name is <username>.<pid>.<count> where:
  • <username> is a user-defined string. If the value is not assigned, then it is unknown.
  • <pid> is the watsond Process ID (PID) for the Parent PID (PPID) of the watsond PPID (which matches the PID reported in who - u command).
  • <count> represents the log file's numerical position in the sequence of multiple segments of the log for an individual session.
Note: If more than one file with the same name exists, a distinguishing numeric suffix is added to the file name.

When a process with a given <pid> exits, the next watson daemon will append the .done suffix to the name of the log file.

The key characteristics of the Watson shell log are the following:
  • A designated log is maintained for each user provisioned with Watson shell.
  • The log contains host, date, and time information.
  • The log does not store a user password in any form.
  • The log identifies a user and all the commands entered by the user.
  • The log rotation is defined by the file size and is done automatically.
  • Only root users have access to the Watson shell log files.

The Watson shell logs from all the SPS nodes are aggregated on the Active AdminCLI pod in /var/log/sps/watson.log file.

Configuration of Watson shell logging

Watson shell logging can be configured with a configuration file. The configuration file allows a user to enable or disable logging on the system. If logging is enabled, logging reports can then be customized. The changes are accepted upon the start of a new watsond daemon or the restart of an existing watsond daemon (a user session). The following applies to Watson shell logging:
  • The configuration parameters are stored in the /etc/userlog.conf file.
  • Use vi /etc/userlog.conf command to modify via /etc/userlog.conf file.
  • To customize logging reports, logging must be enabled.
The following table describes the configuration parameters of Watson shell logs.
Table 31. Configuration parameters of Watson shell logs
Parameter Description Values Notes
ENABLED This parameter controls whether or not to perform logging of subsequent user sessions. Y or N Default: Y
TOTAL_MAXIMUM_SIZE This parameter defines the maximum space occupied by all the files in /var/log/watson directory.

1000000-2000000000 bytes

 Default: 1000000
FILE_MAXIMUM_SIZE This parameter defines the maximum size of a single log file.

100000-1000000 bytes per file

 Default: 200000 bytes
RESPONSE_MAXIMUM_SIZE This parameter defines the maximum response logged following each user input. 0-10000 bytes logged per keystroke 0 = no limit

Default: 250 bytes
USERS_TO_LOG This parameter is a comma-separated list of user names that require logging. Variable characters Default: all

By default this applies to all users.
USERS_NOT_TO_LOG This parameter is a comma-separated list of user names that do not require logging. Variable characters By default the list is empty.

This selection overrides USERS_TO_LOG.

Kubectl

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

https://opentracing.io/docs/overview/what-is-tracing/

Trace example with kubectl

The following is an example of a trace result in kubectl. The text has been formatted for readability.

{  'host': 'sps-pc-7cbf4cc765-tzhtk',
   'level': 'ERROR',
   'log': {  'classname': 'com.nokia.tpapps.subscribersync.observer.EntityResponseObserver:112',
             'message': 'Unable to update the sync operation for batch : '
