Kibana may also be used to view trace information.

Kibana

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Trace example with Kibana

The following is an example of a trace result in Kibana.
To view more information, expand the trace and select View single document.
Selecting View single document displays table and JSON formats of the entire trace.

To view surrounding traces, select View surrounding documents.

A list of other traces is displayed. Each trace may be expanded.

The following is an example of an expanded trace. Both table and JSON views are available.

Note: Traces may also be viewed in kubectl.

Alarms

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

SPS alarms are written to stdout and will be processed/directed by fluentd. They can then be forwarded to northboard systems or stored in a database, and they can be indexed, viewed, and searched by standard tools such as Elasticsearch and Kibana.

SPS can be deployed with an optional SPS Telemetry package which includes an alarm manager.

Alarm administration

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

Alarms are generated to alert operators of abnormal behavior. Alarms are raised by any of the SPS CNF microservices. These alarms are meant to be sent to the Element Management System (EMS) that displays them.

The alarming service is provided across a cluster of machines in a cloud environment and supports the following:
  • southbound interface that allows applications to generate alarms
  • alarm management that includes alarm processing, storage and lifecycle management
  • northbound interface (SNMP v2c/v3) that reports alarms to the EMS

Active alarm table and alarm logs

Active alarms are stored in the ETCD backend. To see active alarms, run the following command on the Active AdminCLI container:
curl http://localhost:8182/api/alma/alarms | python -m json.tool

The size of the active alarm table is stored in <alma.activeAlarmTableSize>. By default, the size of the active alarm table is 1. This value represents the number of units where 1 unit = 1000 count of alarms. The range of the active alarm table is [1;1024].

If the storage backend is down, then the system sends a trap to the SNMP manager with alarm id 2111111111 trying to reach ETCD. If the system is not able to communicate with ETCD, then the system stops processing alarms or sending traps of any alarm.

Brevity control

Sometimes on a site, alarms of a similar nature may be triggered at the same time. To a northbound management system, there will be a burst of alarms arriving which can cause overload. For example, there are multiple instances of a service running in a cluster when a network partition occurs. If half of your service instances can no longer reach the database, each service instance will send an alarm if it cannot communicate with the database. This results in hundreds of alarms being sent to the northbound management system. Brevity control will allow you to configure the SPS to send a limited number of alarms that are of a similar nature but are enough to help identify the root cause of what is happening at that time and avoid going into overload. Brevity control is introduced to control the number of similar alarms that are sent.

Brevity control applies to alarms and only allows a specific number of the same alarms to pass, dropping the rest of the alarms created within the particular interval.

Brevity control is introduced at both the Application and AdminCLI pods inside the /etc/td-agent/td-agent.conf file. Logs related to Brevity control on alarms will be output to stdout.

The alarms are filtered on the parameter keys: alarm.key, id, and severity.

Two variables are introduced at both the AdminCLI and the APP node mappings in the sdc_conf file for brevity control that define how within the brevity_timeframe only a specified number (brevity_num) of the same alarms can be passed, while the rest of the alarms will be dropped, as follows:
  • brevity_timeframe: This allows you to configure timeframe for brevity control. The value should be greater than zero. The default value is set to 10 seconds.
  • brevity_num: This allows you to configure how many re-occurring alarms can be displayed or allowed within the interval of the brevity_timeframe. The value should be greater than zero. The default value is set to 2.
Note: Use of the above configuration at only the AdminCLI pod will configure its brevity control on the AdminCLI pod with its value(s), whereas the Application node will continue using the default value for its brevity control and vice-versa. That is in this example, Brevity control will block the alarms from the event generating nodes so that they do not reach the AdminCLI pod. Alarms will continue to flood on other nodes, but not the AdminCLI pod.

The Brevity control message for dropped alarms will be displayed when the second brevity control occurs on the same alarms.

Supported MIB

In previous versions, the MIB files were used to generate SNMP traps. This has changed and now the MIB files are converted to Java objects in source code, and platform sends SNMP traps according to this new MIB definition.

If NetAct is not used as NMS, then the MIB files provide the content that can be used for SNMP traps.

Enabling alarms

To enable alarms, you configure them. For more information, see the SNMP section in the SPS CNF Installation Guide.

SNMP alarms

The SPS supports a framework for producing SNMP alarms. When an alarm is produced, the SPS maintains Active state until the alarm condition is cleared.
Note: The SPS generates an alarm timestamp in SNMP traps that can be up to five seconds after the actual event time.

Alarm trap

The alarm service provides the ability to send alarms as traps to the SNMP manager.
Note: To specify the SNMP manager, you need to configure the SNMP users parameters after instantiation. To configure the SNMP users, contact Nokia Professional Services.

Alarm identification, uniqueness, field descriptions, and parameters

Alarm uniqueness is a composite of the following parameters:
  • System
  • SpecificProblem

In the NE3S protocol, "noiSystemDistinguishedName" + "noiSpecificProblem" can only define one alarm. So in the API, "system"/"host"/<"container">/<"service">/<"process">+"alarm.id" defines one alarm only. The "system" and "host" are mandatory. The others are the optional. ObjectName is constructed using <host>+<service>#<system>.

The following table lists alarm parameters, their corresponding representation in the OID, and the description of each parameter for systems that use the older NokiaEmsMib, where the following is the OID for the alarm index key in the ETCD database:
1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.1
Table 32. Alarm parameters
Parameter OID Entry OID Example Description
AlarmIndex 1 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.1 Index of the alarm.
ObjectName 2 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.2

<host>+<service>#<system>

The name of the object causing an alarm. The object should include the code module name (e.g. BalanceManager, RatingEngine, ServiceManager, SubscriberModel, etc.).

The Object is formatted as either:

<LocalHostName>#<system>

or

<LocalHostName>+<AlarmInstance>#<system>

<AlarmInstance> is only used when an <AlarmInstance> is applicable. For example, a network heartbeat alarm would set the AlarmInstance to be the name of the remote network element. All other alarms use the first format.

Note:

If "AlarmInstance" is present, a "+" is used to separate the "LocalHostName" and the "AlarmInstance”.

"LocalHostName will reflect the specific host within the SPS that reported the alarm, when applicable. A newly added system alarm may use the VNF Name in the host field.
AlarmType 3 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.3

The defined type of an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard.

The list of key-value bindings for AlarmType is in the "Alarm types" table.
AlarmTime 4 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.4 The value of time in seconds since 00:00:00 UTC, January 1, 1970.
ProbableCause 5 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.5

The name of the problem causing an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard.

The list of key-value bindings for ProbableCause is in the "Alarm probable cause" table.
SpecificProblem 6 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.6 The alarm name. The SpecificProblems field further elaborates the ProbableCause information supplied.
Severity 7 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.7

The perceived severity of an alarm as defined in the X.733 standard...

The list of key-value bindings for Severity is in the "Alarm severity" table.
AdditionalText 9 1.3.6.1.4.1.28458.2.78.5.6.9.1.9 Alarm Data and any additional text provided.
The following table describes additional alarm parameters without OIDs because SPS does not send/set values for these particular parameters.
Table 33. Other Alarm parameters that are not set or sent by SPS
Parameter Description
RepeatCount 0
AutoClearAlarm False when alarm is automatically cleared.
OmdbKey False when alarm is automatically cleared.
OmText False when alarm is automatically cleared.
AlarmSource False when alarm is automatically cleared.
AlarmUUID False when alarm is automatically cleared.
containerFullName The full name of the container in the format: extension.container_Name
VNFCFullName The VNFC full name of the node that triggered the alarm. Only applies to cloud environments.
SystemName

Name of the system in which the event occurred.

For "system" alarms, they are about the SPS as a whole (e.g. Database failure due to too many DB nodes down). If this is a system alarm, the alarm component will use the VNF system name when reporting the alarm, as opposed to the node's host name that created the alarm.

If the alarm is about a given node, the node's host name that created the alarm is given.
Acknowledgement Acknowledgement of the status of the alarm.
AcknowledgementTime Acknowledgement of the time of the alarm.
The following table lists alarm parameters, their corresponding representation in the OID, and the description of each parameter for NE3S on systems that use the newer NOKIA-ENHANCED-SNMP-SOLUTION-SUITE-ALARM-IRP MIB module, where the following is the OID for the noiAlarmId key in the ETCD database:
1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.1
Table 34. NE3S Alarm parameters
Parameters OID Entry OID Example Description
noiAlarmId 1 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.1 This object represents the alarm identifier of an alarm in the alarm table. It uniquely identifies an entry in the alarm table. The alarmId object is read-only even though it is used as index in the alarm table.
noiAlarmSystemDN 2 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.2 This object represents the System Distinguished Name (SDN) of the alarming object, which represents the faulty resource.
noiAlarmEventTime 3 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.3 This object represents the event time, time of occurrence of the event in the Network Element.
noiAlarmSpecificProblem 4 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.4 This object represents the specific problem assigned to the fault situation.
noiAlarmText 5 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.5 This object represents the alarm text and contains basic information on the fault.
noiAlarmPerceivedSeverity 6 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.6 This object represents the perceived severity of the fault. Value can be set to cleared by the manager to cancel the alarm.
noiAdditionalText 7 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.7 This object represents the additional text and provides further qualification on the fault.
noiAlarmProbableCause 8 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.8 This object represents the probable cause of the alarm.
noiAlarmEventType 9 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.9 This ojbect represents the event type.
noiAlarmNotificationId 10 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.10 This object represents the notification identifier. It is a unique value for a notification.
noiAckState 11 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.11 This object represents the acknowledgement status of the alarm. If the agent does not support the concept of acknowledgement, than the value 'indeterminate' shall be used.
noiAckTime 12 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.12 This object represent the time of the last modification of the acknowledgement state of an alarm in the alarm table.
noiAlarmAckUserId 13 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.13 This object represent the user who made the last modification of the acknowledgement state of an alarm in the alarm table.
noiAlarmUUID 14 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.14 This object represents the alarm string identifier of an alarm in the alarm table. It uniquely identifies an alarm.
noiAlarmAdditionalText2 15 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.15 This object represents the alarm additional text 2.
noiAlarmAdditionalText3 16 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.16 This object represents the alarm additional text 3.
noiAlarmAdditionalText4 17 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.17 This object represents the alarm additional text 4.
noiAlarmAdditionalText5 18 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.18 This object represents the alarm additional text 5.
noiAlarmAdditionalText6 19 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.19 This object represents the alarm additional text 6.
noiAlarmAdditionalText7 20 .1.3.6.1.4.1.94.7.1.4.2.1.20 This object represents the alarm additional text 7.
The following table maps Nokia alarm type values to NE3S event types for the AlarmType parameter as defined in the supported MIB.
Table 35. Alarm types
Nokia alarm type Value NE3S event type Value Description
1 communicationAlarm 2 communicationAlarm This alarm type is used when an object detects a communications error.
2 qualityOfServiceAlarm 11 qualityOfServiceAlarm This alarm type is used to report a failure in the quality of service of a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 5 integrityViolation This alarm type is used to report an integrity violation in a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 8 operationalViolation This alarm type is used to report an operational violation in managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 9 physicalViolation This alarm type is used to report a physical violation in a manged object
3 processingErrorAlarm 13 securityViolation This alarm type is used to report a security violation in a managed object.
3 processingErrorAlarm 15 timeDomainViolation This alarm type is used to report a time domain violation in a managed object.
4 equipmentAlarm 4 equipmentAlarm This alarm type is used to report a failure in the equipment.
5 environmentalAlarm 3 environmentalAlarm This alarm type is used to report a problem in the environment.

SPS application alarms

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia
All application alarms are written to stdout. The application alarms are the following:
  • Call Control alarms
  • Subscriber Model and Lifecycle alarms
  • Sy alarms
  • Rating Engine alarms
  • Service Model alarms
  • Notification Client alarms
  • Notification Service alarms
  • LDAP alarms
  • Service Manager alarms
  • Balance Manager alarms
  • NRF alarms
Note: AutoClear is described in the following tables as being "yes" or "true" or "no" or "false". AutoClear: yes or true means that the alarm will be cleared once the condition or scenario has recovered from whatever caused the alarm. AutoClear: no or false means that the alarm must be cleared manually.
Note: The Alarm ID given for each alarm in all of these tables is displayed on SPS for all alarms. When the NokiaEmsMib MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is not sent in the SNMP trap. However, when the NokiaEnhancedSnmpSolutionSuiteAlarmIrp MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is sent in the SNMP trap.

Call Control alarms

The following table lists the alarms generated by Call Control.

Alarm uniqueness is a composite of Specific-Problem and Probable Cause. Within the list of supported Call Control alarms, some alarms have only one set of Specific-Problem + Probable-Cause while others have multiple combinations of these attribute pairings. Regardless of whether one or more combination of Specific-Problem and Probable-Cause exists, each set is considered a distinct alarm.
Note: Device Lookup Failed Alarm and Barring State Alarm are also raised by Sy.
Table 38. Call Control alarms
Service SpecificProblem Other alarm parameters and behavioral characteristics
SPS_CONTROL Device Lookup Failed

Alarm_ID: 310811

System: No

ProbableCause: authenticationFailure

AdditionalText: DEVICEID=[SubscriptionId: <type>:<value>]

e.g.

DEVICEID=[SubscriptionId: END_USER_E164: 390000000000001, SubscriptionId: END_USER_IMSI: 391000000000001]

SPECIFICREASON=Device Lookup Failed

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SPS_CONTROL Service-Context-Id validation fails - Service-Context-Id missing

Alarm_ID: 310804

System: No

ProbableCause: authenticationFailure

AdditionalText: SPECIFICREASON=Service-Context-Id validation fails - Service-Context-Id missing

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes

SPS_CONTROL Requested Action Type is unsupported by system

(1) REFUND_ACCOUNT

(2) CHECK_BALANCE

(3) PRICE_ENQUIRY

e.g.

UNSUPPORTEDACTIONTYPE=CHECK_BALANCE is not supported

SPECIFICREASON=Requested Action Type is unsupported by system

ProbableCause: authenticationFailure

AutoClear: yes

e.g.

Subscriber Model and Lifecycle alarms

The following table lists Subscriber Model and Lifecycle alarms.
Note: All alarms listed in the following table have Specific-Problem and Additional-Text values containing one or more new lines (i.e. "/n") as returned by the application's error handling code in the Subscriber Model and LifeCycle resource bundles. The representation of new lines can vary from one SNMP Manager to the next. If, for some reason, issues are encountered relating to the presence of new lines in the SNMP trap variable bindings for Specific-Problem and Additional-Text, contact Nokia Support for more information.
Table 39. Subscriber Model and Lifecycle alarms
Service SpecificProblem Other alarm parameters and behavioral characteristics
SUBSCRIBER Custom data dictionary attribute does not exist.

Alarm_ID: 310205

System: No

ProbableCause: softwareError

AdditionalText: ERRORDESCRIPTION=Error Reference Number: CUSTOMDATADICT_00007. The attribute "{0}" does not exist in custom data dictionary.

ERRORMESSAGE=Custom data dictionary attribute does not exist.

LOCATIONOFERROR=Subscriber Model

Where {0} contains attribute context and name.

SPECIFICREASON=Custom data dictionary does not exist.

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SUBSCRIBER Invalid device identity format.

Alarm_ID: 310201

System: No

ProbableCause: softwareError

AdditionalText: ERRORDESCRIPTION=Error Reference Number: DEVICE_00004. "{0}" is not a valid value for identity type "{1}".

ERRORMESSAGE=Invalid device identity format.

LOCATIONOFERROR=Subscriber Model

Where {1} is E164, IMSI, MSISDN, NAI, SIP_URI, PRIVATE, IMEI or UUID

SPECIFICREASON=Invalid device identity format.

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SUBSCRIBER Device does not exist.

Alarm_ID: 310202

System: No

ProbableCause: softwareError

AdditionalText: ERRORDESCRIPTION=Error Reference Number: DEVICE_00009. Could not fetch the device with id "{0}".

ERRORMESSAGE=Device does not exist.

LOCATIONOFERROR=Subscriber Model

Where {1} is E164, IMSI, MSISDN, NAI, SIP_URI, PRIVATE, IMEI or UUID

SPECIFICREASON=Device does not exist.

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SUBSCRIBER Account does not exist.

Alarm_ID: 310203

System: No

ProbableCause: softwareError

AdditionalText: ERRORDESCRIPTION= Error Reference Number: ACCOUNT_00003. Could not fetch account with id "{0}".

ERRORMESSAGE=Account does not exist.

LOCATIONOFERROR=Subscriber Model

SPECIFICREASON=Account does not exist.

AlarmType: processingErrorAlarm

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes

AdditionalText: SOAP action(<Message.getServer().getSoapAction()>) could not be completed. Notification [id=<Message.getId()>, templateName=<Message.getTemplateName()>, server=(<Message.getServer()>)], Subscriber <Message.getSubscriberId()>

AlarmType: communicationAlarm

Severity: major

AutoClear: yes

SPS platform alarms

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

The SPS platform has many alarms configured out-of-box.

Overview

The SPS platform alarms are the following:
  • CDR alarms
  • Local system monitoring alarms
  • Network monitoring alarms
  • Other platform alarms
  • SPS Telemetry alarms (optional)

CDR alarms

Table 49. Reprocessor stream alerts
Stream status Code Message Details
Starting CG001 Connection to Redis server 'xxx' failed. This may happen if Redis is down when streams are started.
Running CG008 Error in reprocessing rejected records: xxx An unknown error has occurred. The explanation should provide more details about the problem.
Running CG009 Unexpected end of rejected records list This may happen if there are multiple reprocessing hosts using the same Redis database.
Running CG010 Too many rejected records: xxx There are too many rejected records to handle at once. Another scheduled round is needed.
Table 50. Configuration stream alerts
Stream status Code Message Details
Starting CG001 Connection to Redis server ‘xxx’ failed. Make sure that your Redis server is up and running.
Starting/Running CG008 Configuration update failed: xxx An unexpected error occurred. Check the node logs for more information.
Starting CG011 Unable to instantiate custom configuration and validation class: xxx The custom validation class file could not be found. Make sure that parameter CustomConfigurationClass has been set correctly.
Starting CG012 Connection to Data Refinery database ‘xxx’ failed. Error: xxx Make sure the database parameters have been set correctly. Check the error message to help determine the problem.
Running CG013 Error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: xxx There is some problem with Redis itself. The explanation should provide more details about the problem.
Running CG014 Redis command execution error. Error: xxx Redis command execution failed. Check the log for more details.
Running CG015 Validation of the latest configuration failed (and is not taken into use). Reason: xxx Validation of configuration data failed. Check the reasons given and correct the problem before running the node again.
Running CG016 Distribution rules updated. Distribution rules were changed and updated successfully.
Running CG017 Field mappings updated. Field mapping was changed and updated successfully.
Running CG018 Reading field mapping file failed. Error: xxx Field name mapping is not found. This probably means that there is something wrong with the CFG package of the CG Configuration Node.
Running CG019 Lookup draft tables reverted to currently published state. Configuration draft tables have been reverted to the state at which they were at previous successful publishing.
Running CG040 Published table xxx will not be visible in the UI, since the draft table is not configured to be a lookup table and therefore not visible in the UI. The draft table is not configured to be a lookup table and therefore neither the draft nor the published table will be visible in the UI. If the table needs to be visible and editable through the UI, the draft table configuration should be checked, fixed and published again.
Starting / Running CG042 Configuration cannot be modified while another configuration update is ongoing. Wait until the other update is finished and schedule the node again. Another node is holding the configuration lock. The lock will be released after the other update is finished. In case of an irrecoverable error, the lock will expire in 30 seconds.
Table 51. Output stream alerts
Stream status Code Message Details
Starting CG001 Connection to Redis server 'xxx' failed. This may happen if Redis is down when streams are started.
Running CG008 Error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: xxx An unknown error has occurred. The explanation provides more details about the problem.
Starting CG012 Connection to Data Refinery database ‘xx’ failed. Error: xxx Make sure that the database parameters have been set correctly.
Running CG013 Data Refinery database execution error. Error: xxx An error has occurred while trying to execute SQL query, see the error message for more details.
Running CG030 Number of files in stream link buffers exceeded the configured limit, pausing collection. Limit was: xxx, the maximum number of files in a link buffer was: xxx.

At least one of the link buffers in the stream contains more than the allowed number of files.

Check that all nodes are running properly. Once the buffers are empty, collection will start normally again.
Running CG031 Link buffers are empty, collection started again. All stream link buffers are empty, collection will work normally again.
Table 52. Business logic stream alerts
Stream status Code Message Details
Starting CG001 Connection to Redis server ‘xxx’ failed. This may happen if Redis is down when streams are started.
Starting CG002 Unable to instantiate custom MappingTransformer: xxx Check the value of node parameter CustomMapperClass.
Starting CG004 Unable to instantiate CustomPartialCheckerClass, disabling partial handling. The exception was: xxx Check the value of node parameter CustomPartialCheckerClass.
Running CG005 Rejected xx record(s): xxx There is some problem with Redis itself or in custom mapper class. The explanation provides more details about the problem.
Running CG008 Error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: xxx An unknown error has occurred. The explanation provides more details about the problem.
Running CG043 Error occurred xxx time(s) during mapping: xxx Mapping of fields failed because of invalid input message. More info about the error in logs.
Table 53. Kafka input stream alerts
Stream status Code Message Details
Starting/Running CG008 Error occured xxx time(s) during processing: xxx An unknown error has occured. The explanation provides more details about the problem.
Running CG014 Redis command execution error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: xxx Redis command execution failed. Check the log for more details.
Running CG020 Mapper queue size is above threshold.

There are not enough Business logic streams to handle the collected input records. More Business logic streams need to be instantiated.

The threshold configured in CG Kafka Node with node parameter QueueSizeLowThreshold has been reached.
Running CG021 Mapper queue size is back below threshold. Business logic stream is able to handle the collected input records again. Queue size is back to below or equal to the value of node parameter QueueSizeClearThreshold in CG Kafka Node.
Running CG022 Output stream queue size is above threshold.

There are not enough Output streams to handle the collected input records. More Output streams need to be instantiated.

The threshold configured in CG Mapper Node with node parameter QueueSizeLowThreshold has been reached.
Running CG023 Output stream queue size is back below threshold. Output stream is able to handle the collected input records again. Queue size is back to below or equal to the value of node parameter QueueSizeClearThreshold in CG Mapper Node.
Running CG024 Database utilization percentage is above threshold.

Database storage utilization is high.

The threshold configured in CG Kafka Node with node parameter DatabaseUsageLowThreshold has been reached.
Running CG025 Database utilization percentage is back to below threshold. Database usage percentage is back to below or equal to the value of node parameter DatabaseUsageClearThreshold in CG Kafka Node.
Running CG028 Collection of Kafka messages stopped due to xxx.

Kafka input stream has paused the collection of input records. This happens when any of database usage, Business logic stream queue size or Output stream queue size exceeds the defined high threshold.

The high thresholds are configured with node parameters DatabaseUsageHighThreshold or QueueSizeHighThreshold in CG Kafka Node and CG Mapper Node.
Running CG029 Collection of Kafka messages has been resumed

Database usage, Business logic stream queue size and Output stream queue size have all fallen below the defined low thresholds and Kafka input stream is no longer pausing the collection.

The low thresholds are configured with node parameters DatabaseUsageLowThreshold or QueueSizLowThreshold in CG Kafka Node and CG Mapper Node.
Running CG032 Decoding error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: xxx The node received an unexpected message from the Kafka topic that could not be decoded.
Running CG033 Error occurred xxx time(s) while connected to the Kafka broker: xxx An unexpected error occurred while connected to the Kafka broker, more information about the error in logs.
Running CG034 Error occurred xxx time(s) while committing the message to Kafka: xxx The received message could not be committed to Kafka after multiple attempts. The message will be reprocessed.
Running CG035 Missing CDR session information fields (error occurred xxx time(s)): xxx The received CDR message did not have the required fields (sessionId, sequence number) to be stored into Redis. It will be treated as an EDR.
Running CG036 Error occurred xxx time(s) during processing: detected xxx failed Kafka consumer thread(s). Check connectivity towards Redis as well as node internal storage logs. At least one Kafka consumer thread was unexpectedly terminated.
Running CG041 Failed to query database size limit:xxx Error occurred when querying database size limit.

Local system monitoring alarms

The following table lists the local system monitoring alarms.
Note: All "service down" and "service instance down" alarms have been combined with the other "service down" and "service instance down" alarms into their respective "<Service Name> Service is Down" and "<Service Name> Instance is Down" alarms. For example, "TRSCHEDULER service down" and "TRSCHEDULER service instance down" are now described as part of the <Service Name> Service is Down and <Service Name> Instance is Down alarms in this table.
Note:
Note: AutoClear is described in the following tables as being "yes" or "true" or "no" or "false". AutoClear: yes and true mean that the alarm will be cleared once the condition or scenario has recovered from whatever caused the alarm. AutoClear: no or false means that the alarm must be cleared manually.
Note: The Alarm ID given for each alarm in all of therse tables is displayed on SPS for all alarms. When the NokiaEmsMib MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is not sent in the SNMP trap. However, when the NokiaEnhancedSnmpSolutionsSuiteAlarmIrp MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is sent in the SNMP trap.
Table 54. Local system monitoring alarms (SPS Fastpass mode - NokiaEnhancedSnmpSolutionSuiteAlarmIrp MIB)
Service SpecificProblem Other alarm parameters and behavioral characteristics
SYSTEM System out of service

Alarm_ID: 310403

System: No

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: Target system is not in service.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SYSTEM System in overload state

Alarm_ID: 310401

System: No

ProbableCause: PERFORMANCE_DEGRADED

AdditionalText: Target system is in an overload state, <usage_state>. Affected components: [<components>].

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor, major, critical

AutoClear: no
SYSTEM System in resource critical overload state

Alarm_ID: 310402

System: No

ProbableCause: PERFORMANCE_DEGRADED

AdditionalText: Target system is in an overload state, resource critical. Components affected: [<components>].

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: critical

AutoClear: no
DDM_APPS Diameter Message Validation Failure

Alarm_ID: 311601

System: No

ProbableCause: AUTHENTICATION_FAILURE

AdditionalText: This alarm is raised when a diameter message validation error occurs.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes

AdditionalText: This alarm is raised when a diameter SLF lookup failure occurs.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DDM_APPS Message Rate Exceeded

Alarm_ID: 311603

System: No

ProbableCause: CONGESTION

AdditionalText: Throttling has been applied to Diameter messages.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SYSTEM+<Component Name> Component is Down
Note: The component can be the SM or the ME in the AdditionalText. For example, for the ME component, the text will be "ME Component is Down".

If SPS is running in Generic mode (NokiaEmsMibMIB is configured), this single alarm will be raised as two different alarms for each component.

Alarm_ID: 310404

System: Yes

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: Component <Component Name> is down.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: critical

AutoClear: no
SYSTEM+<Service Name> Service is Down

If SPS is running in Generic mode (NokiaEmsMib MIB is configured), this single alarm will be raised as different alarms for each service.

Note: The service name in the AdditionalText can be one of:
  • LOADBALANCER
  • AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER
  • CDR
  • CHARGING
  • DIAMETERIO
  • LTM
  • NOTIFICATION
  • TRSCHEDULER
  • KAFKA
  • PROVISIONING
  • ROLLBACK
  • TEM
  • XDR
  • SM

Alarm_ID: 310405

System: Yes

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: Service <Service Name> is down.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: critical

AutoClear: no
SYSTEM+<Service Name> Instance is Down
If SPS is running in Generic mode (NokiaEmsMib MIB is configured), this single alarm will be raised as different alarms for each service.
Note: The service name in the AdditionalText can be one of:
  • LOADBALANCER
  • AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER
  • CDR
  • CHARGING
  • DIAMETERIO
  • LTM
  • NOTIFICATION
  • PROVISIONING
  • ROLLBACK
  • KAFKA
  • TRSCHEDULER
  • TEM
  • XDR
  • SM

Alarm_ID: 310406

System: No

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: Service <Service Name> is down on node <Host Id>.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SYSTEM+<Service Name> Service has less than N instances in service
Note: The service name in the AdditionalText can be any of the following:
  • CHARGING
  • SM
  • PROVISIONING
  • CDR
  • NOTIFICATION

Alarm_ID: 310407

System: Yes

ProbableCause: THRESHOLD_CROSSED

AdditionalText: There are less than ${nFactor} (out of ${nFactor}+${kFactor}) ${serviceName} instances in service, which may jeopardize the ability to handle a full peak engineered load.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
N/A SPS Site is Down Temporarily for an SU action

Alarm_ID: N/A

System: N/A

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: SPS will automatically return to service shortly

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
SPS_COMMON+<Remote SPS ID>-<Component> SPS forced to treat component of another SPS site In Service, as if it had received an In Service heartbeat from the site.

Alarm_ID: 310707

System: Yes

ProbableCause: UNSPECIFIED_REASON

AdditionalText: The tool force-remote-site-in-service was used to indicate that a component of the remote site should be treated as In Service, even though heartbeats are not being received.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION_ALARM

Severity: warning

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<Remote SPS ID>-<Component> SPS returned to normal heartbeat treatment for a component of another SPS

Alarm_ID: 310709

System: Yes

ProbableCause: UNSPECIFIED_REASON

AdditionalText: The tool force-remote-site-in-service was used to clear a component of another SPS that was previously forced In Service by the tool.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION_ALARM

Severity: warning

AutoClear: yes
SPS_COMMON+<Remote SPS ID>-<Component> SPS automatically reset to normal heartbeat treatment for a component of another SPS

Alarm_ID: 310708

System: Yes

ProbableCause: UNSPECIFIED_REASON

AdditionalText: The heartbeat service returned to normal operation, as communication has been reliable for the expected period of time.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION_ALARM

Severity: warning

AutoClear: yes
SPS_COMMON+<Remote SPS ID>-<Component> A component of another SPS was determined to be Out Of Service

Alarm_ID: 310705

System: Yes

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: Please contact Nokia

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<Remote SPS ID> Diameter communication to another SPS is Down

Alarm_ID: 310706

System: Yes

ProbableCause: UNSPECIFIED_REASON

AdditionalText: Please contact Nokia

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE Data migration in progress

Alarm_ID: 311250

System: Yes

ProbableCause: UNSPECIFIED_REASON

AdditionalText: The DB monitor has detected that data migration is in progress in the local DB cluster

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE+<namespace> Aerospike usable disk resources are low.

Alarm_ID: 311252

System: No

ProbableCause: STORAGE_CAPACITY_PROBLEM

AdditionalText: Can be one of:

  • For minor or major severity: Aerospike has only <percentage> of usable disk resources. Aerospike defragmentation is unable to keep up with the current load.
  • For critical severity: Aerospike has only <percentage> of usable disk resources, which are critically low and may result in a stop-writes if the percentage drops below 5%.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity:

Minor alarm: threshold = 25

Major alarm: threshold = 20

Critical alarm: threshold = 15

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE+<namespace> Aerospike free memory is low.

Alarm_ID: 311253

System: No

ProbableCause: STORAGE_CAPACITY_PROBLEM

AdditionalText: Can be one of:
  • For minor severity: Aerospike has only <percentage> of free memory, which is considered low.
  • For major severity: Aerospike has only <percentage> of free memory, which is considered very low.
  • For critical severity: Percentage of free memory capacity is critically low and may result in a stop-writes if the percentage drops below 10%.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity:

Minor alarm:

threshold = 20

Major alarm:

threshold = 15

Critical alarm:

threshold = 13

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE+<namespace> Aerospike has entered stop-writes mode.

Alarm_ID: 311254

System: No

ProbableCause: STORAGE_CAPACITY_PROBLEM

AdditionalText: Until cause is reverted, Aerospike will reject all write-requests from other components in the system.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: critical

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE Aerospike Server Instance is Down

Alarm_ID: 311251

System: No

ProbableCause: OUT_OF_SERVICE

AdditionalText: —

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
The following table describe the alarms that are raised in generic mode. Generic mode means that the NokiaEmsMib MIB is configured.
Note: If SPS is instantiated in Generic mode (NokiaEmsMib MIB is configured), the alarms with Alarm IDs 310404, 310405, 310406 are split into multiple alarms.

Network monitoring alarms

The following table lists the network monitoring alarms.

Note: AutoClear is described in the following tables as being "yes" or "true" or "no" and "false". AutoClear: yes or true means that the alarm will be cleared once the condition or scenario has recovered from whatever caused the alarm. AutoClear: no or false means that the alarm must be cleared manually.
Note: The Alarm ID given for each alarm in all of these tables is displayed on SPS for all alarms. When the NokiaEmsMib MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is not sent in the SNMP trap. However, when the NokiaEnhancedSnmpSolutionSuiteAlarmIrp MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is sent in the SNMP trap.
Table 56. Network monitoring alarms
Service SpecificProblem Other alarm parameters and behavioral characteristics
DIAMETER+<RemoteOriginHost> Peer connection detected

Alarm_ID: 311802

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: System has detected a peer connection for <RemoteOriginHost> using protocol <protocol>.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DIAMETER+<RemoteOriginHost> Peer disconnect detected

Alarm_ID: 311803

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: System has detected a peer disconnect for <RemoteOriginHost> using protocol <protocol>.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DIAMETER+<RemoteOriginHost> SCTP address available

Alarm_ID: 311804

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: System has detected an SCTP address is available for <RemoteOriginHost>. IP address <ip address>.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DIAMETER+<RemoteOriginHost> SCTP address unavailable

Alarm_ID: 311805

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: System has detected an SCTP address is unavailable for <RemoteOriginHost>. IP address <ip address>.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DIAMETER Too many routing failures

Alarm_ID: 311806

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: Check contents of the countable event 'Failed Routing Attempts'.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: yes
DIAMETER APP node unable to connect to remote peer, retry continues to fail.

Alarm_ID: 311807

System: No

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: APP node is unable to connect to <originHost> using protocol <protocol>. If the particular peer is connected with the ME in general, and the alarm does not clear by itself, Nokia recommends to RESTART the AppServer on this APP node, then CLEAR the alarm. If the alarm comes back, contact Nokia support.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
<Host> Heartbeat service on Central Management not started.

Alarm_ID: 310710

System: Yes

ProbableCause: APPLICATION_SUBSYSTEM_FAILURE

AdditionalText: It is possible a subsystem was unavailable at startup. Restart the application server on the affected Central Management.

AlarmType: PROCESSING_ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<RemoteSiteName> Heartbeat missing with member. Component for site still seen as in service.

Alarm_ID: 310703

System: Yes

ProbableCause: THRESHOLD_CROSSED

AdditionalText: Heartbeat missing with member. At least one other member we received heartbeats from can see the component of the remote site as in service.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<RemoteSiteName> Heartbeat missing with member. Treating the component for the remote site as OOS.

Alarm_ID: 310701

System: Yes

ProbableCause: THRESHOLD_CROSSED

AdditionalText: All members reporting a heartbeat agree that the component for the remote site is unreachable or OOS. At least one of the reporters is from another location. Treating the component for the remote site as OOS.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<RemoteSiteName> Heartbeat missing with member. No member from another location responded. Cannot declare component OOS.

Alarm_ID: 310704

System: Yes

ProbableCause: THRESHOLD_CROSSED

AdditionalText: The remote site is unreachable or OOS. Only members at this location can be reached by heartbeat. The problem may be with the sites at this location. Treating the component for the remote site by its last known status.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SPS_COMMON+<RemoteSiteName> Heartbeat missing with member. Treating the site as OOS. (2 locations)

Alarm_ID: 310702

System: Yes

ProbableCause: THRESHOLD_CROSSED

AdditionalText: The heartbeat between this site and the remote site is down. Treating the component for the remote site as OOS.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE Waiting for data to resynchronize from remote sites.

Alarm_ID: 311202

System: Yes

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

AdditionalText: The local site will remain OOS while waiting for data to resynchronize from remote sites.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
DB_AEROSPIKE+<RemoteSiteName> At least one node has detected CLUSTER_DOWN, CLUSTER_INACTIVE, or CLUSTER_WINDOW_SHIP for the remote site state.

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Severity: critical

Auto-Clear: no

ProbableCause: COMMUNICATIONS_PROTOCOL_ERROR

Additional text: The local site has determined that cross-data-replication is BEHIND or OVERFLOWED. The system has detected local SPS sync state is in a '${syncState}' state

AlarmType: COMMUNICATION ALARM

Auto-Clear: no

Severity: major

Other platform alarms

The following table lists security alarms, threshold alarms, and the alarms raised for the ETCD cluster.
Note: AutoClear is described in the following tables as being "yes" or "true" or "no" or "false". AutoClear: yes or true means that the alarm will be cleared once the condition or scenario has recovered from whatever caused the alarm. AutoClear: no or false means that the alarm must be cleared manually.
Note: The Alarm ID given for each alarm in all of these tables is displayed on SPS for all alarms. When the NokiaEmsMib MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is not sent in the SNMP trap. However, when the NokiaEnhancedSnmpSolutionSuiteAlarmIrp MIB is used to integrate any NMS, the Alarm ID is sent in the SNMP trap.
Table 57. Other platform alarms
Service SpecificProblem Other alarm parameters and behavioral characteristics
CHAS Node transitioning to active

Alarm ID: 3000100

ProbableCause: Processing error

AdditionalText: Indicates the keepalived component has experienced a failover. This alarm is triggered when the new Master transitions to ACTIVE.

AlarmType: Application subsystem failure

Severity: Major

AutoClear: yes
NTP Clock state indeterminate

Alarm ID: 3000440

ProbableCause: remoteNodeTransmissionError

AdditionalText: NTP Internal failure

AlarmType: communicationsAlarm

Severity: Major

AutoClear: yes
NTP Clock not synchronized

Alarm ID: 3000441

ProbableCause: remoteNodeTransmissionError

AdditionalText: NTP No response from external time service.

AlarmType: communicationsAlarm

Severity: Major

AutoClear: yes
NTP Clock state indeterminate

Alarm ID: 3000445

ProbableCause: remoteNodeTransmissionError

AdditionalText: CHRONY Internal failure

AlarmType: communicationsAlarm

Severity: Major

AutoClear: yes
NTP Clock not synchronized

Alarm ID: 3000446

ProbableCause: remoteNodeTransmissionError

AdditionalText: CHRONY No response from external time service.

AlarmType: communicationsAlarm

Severity: Major

AutoClear: yes
SECPAM User account dormant threshold warning - no action taken

Alarm ID: 3001450

ProbableCause: qualityOfServiceAlarm

AdditionalText: A user account has been dormant for an extended time period defined by the WARN_IDLE_LOGINS parameter.

user:%s,service:LockIdleAccounts,protocol:%s,state:true,status:success,days_dormant:%s

AlarmType: thresholdCrossed

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User account dormant threshold exceeded - account locked

Alarm ID: 3001451

ProbableCause: qualityOfServiceAlarm

AdditionalText: A user account has been dormant for an extended time period defined by the WARN_IDLE_LOGINS parameter.

user:%s,service:LockIdleAccounts,protocol:%s,state:true,status:success,days_dormant:%s

AlarmType: thresholdCrossed

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM Excessive authentication failures - user account access disabled

Alarm ID: 3001452

ProbableCause: authenticationFailure

AdditionalText: A user account 'log-in' access is being disabled because the MAX_LOGIN_FAILURES threshold was crossed.

user:%s,service:%s,protocol:%s,state:true,status:success

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User account access re-enabled

Alarm ID: 3001453

ProbableCause: authenticationFailure

AdditionalText: A user account 'log-in' access is being disabled because the MAX_LOGIN_FAILURES threshold was crossed.

user:%s,service:%s,protocol:%s,state:true,status:success

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM IP routing table modification detected

Alarm ID: 3001454

ProbableCause: infoModDetected

AdditionalText: An entry in the node's routing table has been added or removed.

service:rtmon,status:started || service:rtmon,status:stopped || user:%s,service:rtmon,detail:User has attempted to modify IP routing table"

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: major

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User has attempted to modify log

Alarm ID: 3001460

ProbableCause: infoModDetected

AdditionalText: An unauthorized user attempted to modify a security log. This is associated with the default set of audits (specifically those with the log keyword) and is always enabled.

user:%s,service:audit,protocol:n/a,state:true,status:success

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User Account File has been modified by user

Alarm ID: 3000461

ProbableCause: infoModDetected

AdditionalText: User or group information files such as group, password or shadow have been opened (associated with the access set of audits and can be enabled at discretion of admin). This alarm is also generated when the config audit key is triggered. Several of these are specified in the default set of audits.

user:%s,service:audit,protocol:n/a,state:true,status:success,file:%s

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User has modified date/time

Alarm ID: 3000462

ProbableCause: infoModDetected

AdditionalText:

The time or date has been changed (associated with the

time-change set of audits and can be enabled at discretion of

admin).

user:%s,service:audit,protocol:n/a,state:true,status:success

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User has attempted to access nonpermissible file

Alarm ID: 3000463

ProbableCause: unauthAccessAttempt

AdditionalText: User account files have been modified (associated with the identity set of audits and can be enabled at discretion of admin).

user:%s,service:audit,protocol:n/a,state:true,status:success,file:%s,mode:%s

AlarmType: securityViolation

Severity: minor

AutoClear: no
SECPAM User has attempted to modify root crontab

Alarm ID: 3000464

ProbableCause: infoModDetected

AdditionalText: The root user cron table has been modified.

AutoClear: no

Backup and restore

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

The SPS leverages the Nokia CBUR (Backup and Restore) component for backup and restore. CBUR provides support for a variety of backup destinations.

For more information regarding use of Nokia CBUR, see https://confluence.app.alcatel-lucent.com/display/plateng/CBUR+-+Backup+and+Recovery

Scaling

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

This chapter describes scaling in the SPS CNF.

Scaling options

Scaling means increasing or decreasing the number of pods based on the resources that are needed. Scale-in decreases the number of running pods of a particular pod type if the traffic is sufficiently low to recognize that fewer resources are required. Scale-out increases the number of pods of a particular pod type to provide additional capacity. Scale-in and scale-out can be done manually or using autoscaling operation in Kubernetes. The following table describes the availability of manual scaling and autoscaling in SPS CNF.

Table 59. Autoscaling and manual scaling
Pod type Scaling type available
iohd none
charging autoscaling
servicemanager autoscaling
provisioning autoscaling
notification autoscaling
aerospike manual scaling
cdr (multiple pod types) manual scaling
centralmanagement none
kafka none
etcd (csdc) none
zookeeper none
keycloak (ckey) autoscaling
mariadb none

Autoscaling

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Autoscaling is a Kubernetes operation that automatically increases or decreases the number of pods based on the demands of your workloads. When demand is high, autoscaling adds pods to the pods pool. When demand is low, autoscaling scales down the number of pods giving back unused resources.

Autoscaling is handled by Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA), a Kubernetes API resource and controller, and works independently for each pod type. HPA monitors the workload and utilization of resources in a cluster, and based on the current need as well as specified utilization metrics and thresholds, dynamically adjusts the number of pods of a particular pod type. By default the utilization metric is set to CPU utilization.

Note: Scaling down occurs gradually, smoothing out the impact of rapidly fluctuating metric values with a downscale stabilization timer of five minutes.

For more information about Autoscaling and HPA, see Kubernetes documentation.

HPA definition

The HPA for each pod type is defined in the values.yaml file as follows: 

hpa:
    minReplicas: 1
    maxReplicas: 10
    averageCpuUtilization: 80

where:

  • minReplicas is the minimum number of pods running at any time.
  • maxReplicas is the maximum number of pods running at any time regardless of the utilization calculation.
  • averageCpuUtilization is the percentage of the target average used to determine whether a new pod should be instantiated or how many existing pods should be terminated.

Updating HPA configuration

The HPA configuration parameters minReplicas, maxReplicas, and averageCpuUtilization can be updated at the time of installation and post-installation using the helm upgrade command.

Before you update averageCpuUtilization, find out the current CPU utilization.

Note:

Do not use the Kubernetes GUI to find out whether or not the current CPU utilization exceeds the target CPU utilization. Use kubectl -n <namespace> get hpa command for this purpose.

For information about helm and its options, see helm documentation.

Kubernetes GUI

The Kubernetes GUI allows you to see events related to scaling. These events are visible in a number of microservices views such as Deployment, StatefulSet or ReplicaSet. For more information on the Kubernetes GUI, see Kubernetes documentation.

CDR Streams

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

This chapter gives instructions on the operation and maintenance tasks of SPS CDR Streams.

Configuring distribution rules

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Distribution rules define which output records are stored in which files and which directories. The configuration is maintained through lookup tables in Data Refinery UI.

For more information on distribution rules, see CNF Overview in the SPS documentation set.

For more information on publishing lookup configurations, see Chapter Publishing and reverting lookup configuration.

Default distribution rules

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

If no file groups are configured, the characteristics for batch creation are taken from the node parameters as described in the following table. The same applies if a configured file group does not define some of the characteristics.

Default distribution rules

Default behavior Node parameter
Output identifier

None. Empty string will be used to replace possible output identifier in the file name mask.
Output directory CG Distributor Node / TargetDirectory (connection parameter)
Maximum number of records per file CG Mapper Node / RecordsPerBatch
Maximum number of seconds to wait before closing a file CG Mapper Node / SecondsPerBatch
Sequence ID All output files share the same set of sequence numbers.

Defining splitting criteria

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Splitting criteria are reusable expressions which can be used by any number of file groups. Criteria are used for matching output records to correct distribution rules.

To create or modify criteria, update the ‘Split Criteria’ lookup table.

Columns in ‘Split Criteria’ lookup table

Column name Description Valid value Optional
CriteriaId All criteria must have a unique identifier so they can be used by the file groups. Any unique string. No
OutputFieldName The name of the field whose value is used for the comparison.

Field name present in the output record.

If the field is not present, the criteria is evaluated as false.

 No
CriteriaType The type of comparison. See the following table. No
CriteriaValue For simple comparisons, this is the fixed value that the record field value is compared against. See the following table. Empty if this is a dataset comparison. Otherwise mandatory.
Dataset For dataset comparisons this is the name of the lookup table that contains the dataset to be used. The name of an existing lookup table that contains a single column. Empty if this is a simple comparison. Otherwise mandatory.

Because Data Refinery does not support empty values in lookup tables, they must be specified by using the dash (-) character.

Criteria types and values

Criteria type Description Valid values
EXACT_MATCH A strict case-sensitive comparison.

Any string.

Example: abc
REG_EX_MATCH

A pattern match against a regular expression.

For more information on the allowed regular expressions, see the documentation for java.util.regex.Pattern.

 A valid regular expression. Example: abc.*def
GREATER_THAN A numeric comparison.

A valid integer value.

Example: 1
LESS_THAN A numeric comparison.

A valid integer value.

Example: 1000
DATA_SET_EXACT_MATCH Check that the field value matches (case-sensitive) any entry in the specified lookup table.

The name of an existing lookup table that contains a single column.

Example: LT_MSISDN_LIST
DATA_SET_STARTS_WITH_MATCH Check that the field value starts with (case-sensitive) any entry in the specified lookup table.

The name of an existing lookup table that contains a single column.

Example: LT_MSISDN_LIST

Defining distribution rules

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

To create or modify distribution rules, update the ‘Distr Rules’ lookup table. For default values of the optional fields, see Section Default distribution rules.

Columns in ‘Distr Rules’ lookup table

Column name Description Valid value Optional
PriorityRule All rules must have a unique numeric value so that records matching multiple rules will be evaluated deterministically.

Unique integer value.

A lower value indicates a higher priority. Rules are evaluated in priority order.

 No
RuleCriteria List of criteria, all of which must be true for the record to match this file group. Comma-separated list of Criteria IDs as defined in the ‘Split Criteria’ table. No, except for the DEFAULT rule with the lowest priority.
OutputIdentifier Used in forming output filenames. .CDR.5GR Yes
OutputDirectory Path to place all output files for this file group. The path is relative to the output directory configured in the CG Distributor Node. For example: “Sub1/Type1” Yes
SequenceId File groups with the same Sequence ID share the file sequence numbering. Any string value. Yes
RecordsPerBatch Maximum number of records per output file. Any positive integer (>=1) Yes
SecondsPerBatch Maximum seconds elapsed before closing an output file. Any positive integer (>=1) Yes
OutputDisabled

Defines how output records are handled.

If set to 'Y', output records matching this rule are not written in files but filtered out instead.

If set to 'N', output records are stored normally in files.

 Y, N No
RuleDisabled

Defines how a distribution rule is handled.

If set to 'Y', the rule is ignored, and no records are checked against it.

If set to 'N', the rule is used for evaluation normally.

 Y, N No
Description Free-form text field used to describe the file group. Not used for data processing purposes. Free text. Yes

Because Data Refinery does not support empty values, they must be specified using the dash (-) character instead.

Internal format

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

The distribution rule configuration is stored within the database under key “{Config}:DistributionRules” in JSON format. There is no need to examine this value unless you are instructed to do so by support for debugging purposes or if the lookup table data gets corrupted and there is a need to recover the current configuration.

Configuring output file name pattern

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

The file name pattern for output files generated by the Output stream is defined with ASN.1 Encoder Node parameter OutputFileNameCreationMask. To configure the file name pattern, set this parameter for ASN.1 Encoder Node.

Parameter OutputFileNameCreationMask can have the following variables:

Variable Description
&LAST(batchSeq) The batch/file sequence number (format defined in CG Mapper Node).
&LAST(batchSize) The number of output records in batch/file.
&LAST(batchCreation) The batch/file creation timestamp (format defined in CG Mapper Node).
&LAST(outputIdentifier) The part of file name defined in distribution rule configuration. If no value has been configured, this part will be empty.
@&LAST(suffix) The file name suffix used when transferring the file. This must always be defined, and included at the end of the file name mask. When the file has been transferred correctly, the suffix is removed.
The default value for OutputFileNameCreationMask is: 
SPS.&LAST(batchSeq).&LAST(batchCreation)&LAST(outputIdentifier)@&LAST(suffix)

Publishing and reverting lookup configuration

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Lookup tables are used for managing the configuration of distribution rules through Data Refinery UI. After modifications, lookup tables must be published to the database for the configuration changes to take effect.

The lookup configuration currently in use (published) can be seen as read-only lookup tables with suffix P_ in the table names. The corresponding editable draft lookup tables have the same name but without the prefix. If necessary, it is also possible to revert a draft lookup table back to its previous published state.

For more information, see the SPS CNF Overview.

Publishing lookup configuration to database

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

After editing one or several lookup tables in Data Refinery UI and saving the changes, the lookup configuration can be published by running CG Configuration Node in publish mode. Note that all the lookup tables will always be published at the same time.

To publish lookup configuration:

  1. In Data Refinery UI, open the Configuration stream.
  2. Select the CG Configuration Node that is named PUBLISH_CONFIGURATION.
  3. Click Execute now, then verify with Execute.

CG Configuration Node has now been run in publish mode and the latest configuration has been loaded into the database.

Reverting lookup configuration draft to latest published state

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

If there is a need to revert draft lookup tables back to the state of last publishing, you can do that by running CG Configuration Node in revert mode. Reverting copies the data from the published lookup tables back to the draft lookup tables and any changes made to the draft tables are discarded.

To revert lookup configuration:

1. In Data Refinery UI, open the Configuration stream.

2. Select the CG Configuration Node named REVERT_CONFIGURATION.

3. Click Execute now, then verify with Execute.

CG Configuration Node has now been run in revert mode, and the configuration in draft lookup tables has been reverted to the published configuration in the database.

Auditing

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

All the streams use the standard Data Refinery auditing interface, meaning that counters and throughput can be monitored at node level. The audit information captured for each specific node is detailed in the following sections. For more information on Data Refinery auditing, see Data Refinery Functional Description.

In the following tables, the Counter type column indicates the types of counters that are incremented by records coming into the node (left of the = sign) and by outgoing records (right of the = sign). Counter types available are:
  • RecordsIn
  • RecordsOut
  • Filtered
  • Rejected
  • ReprocessedIn
  • Created
  • Duplicated
  • Stored
  • Retrieved
  • ReducedInMerging

Kafka input streams

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Kafka input stream auditing

Node Counter type Details
CG Kafka Node RecordsIn = Stored + Filtered

If the input record cannot be processed for some reason (for instance decoding error), the Filtered counter is incremented. Otherwise it is marked as Stored.

The RecordsIn counter indicates the number of records coming in.

Business logic stream

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Business logic stream auditing

Node Counter type Details
CG Mapper Node Retrieved = Stored + Rejected

Any record rejected during the mapping process increments the Rejected counter.

Otherwise, the Stored counter is incremented.

Output stream

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Output stream auditing

Node Counter type Details
CG Collector Node Retrieved = RecordsOut Each collected output record increments these counters.
ASN.1 Encoder Node RecordsIn = Retrieved = Stored Each generated output record increments these counters.
CG Distributor Node RecordsIn = RecordsOut Each output record in every output file increments these counters.

Reprocessor stream

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Reprocessor stream auditing

Node Counter type Details
CG Reprocessor Node Retrieved = Stored Each input record moved back to processing increments these counters.

CDR decoding

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

The CDRs generated are ASN.1 encoded and are saved as binary files. You can use a decoding tool to decode to plain text. SPS provides a CDR decoding tool called asn1decoder, which can be accessed through the command line on the sps-streams-oam pod.

The tool supports binary data encoded in BER format (ITU-T X.690) and enables the decoding of plain ASN.1 objects, as well as ASN.1 objects encapsulated into a CDR file (3GPP TS 32.297). By default, the tool tries to decode the file headers of the binary files and, if it fails, assumes that there is no header in the file. However, if needed, the headers can be defined explicitly with optional parameters.

Running asn1decoder tool

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia
  1. Log in to the sps-streams-oam pod as nokia user.
  2. The CDR module stores the CDR files on the dr-eventlink-sftp pod. First you need to get the password to the sftp pod. That can be obtained by running command:
    echo $SFTP_PASSWORD
  3. The file to be decoded can then be retrieved by running command:
    sftp $SFTP_USER@$SFTP_HOST:/path/to/cdr_file .

    For example:

    sftp $SFTP_USER@$SFTP_HOST:/cdr/SPS_-_0000000044.20191224_-_1700-0000.CDR .
  4. Use the following command to decode the CDR file:
    asn1decoder path/to/description.asn path/to/cdr_file RootType

    Where you must define,

    • the path to the description file containing the ASN.1 schema. The schema is stored in /home/nokia/description.asn
    • the path to the CDR file to be decoded
    • the name of the root type in the encoded file (as defined in the ASN.1 schema). In the default SPS ASN.1 schema, the root type is called SPSRecord, but the root type can also be found in the description.asn as the name of the first CHOICE element.
    Optional parameters:
    Table 60. Optional parameters
    Parameter Description
    -h, --help Shows helpful information.
    -d, --debug Shows debugging information.
    -o {yaml} Specify output format of the decoded data. Currently, only yaml is supported.
    -file-header {auto, true, false} Specify if the data contains a CDR file header. Default is set to detect automatically.

    Example:

    asn1decoder /home/nokia/description.asn /cdr/SPS01_-_0000000044.20191224_-_1700-0000.CDR SPSRecord
    The command will print the converted CDR file content to standard out. It can be redirected into a file by adding > path/to/converted_file.txt, for example:
    asn1decoder / home/nokia/description.asn /cdr/SPS01_-_0000000044.20191224_-_1700-0000.CDR SPSRecord > /cdr/decoded/SPS01_-_0000000044.20191224_-_1700-0000.CDR.out
    Note: The schema used for decoding CDRs and EDRs in the SPS generic ASN.1 format uses UTF8String instead of OCTET STRING to make the decoded data more readable. This is safe as all the values included in the output records in the SPS generic ASN.1 format are actually string values.

CDR troubleshooting

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Certain problem scenarios cause the streams to generate alerts. The following section provides CDR-specific troubleshooting information.

Records rejected in CG Mapper Node

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

If a record cannot be processed in CG Mapper Node, a warning is raised and the record is rejected and stored within the database under key “rejected{storage}”. The rejected storage is a list of all the rejected records and can be examined through the database command line tool. The records are stored in compressed Data Refinery internal format.

Records rejected in ASN.1 Encoder Node

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

If a record cannot be encoded with the given ASN.1 schema in ASN.1 Encoder Node, it is rejected and stored within the Data Refinery rejected storage. The rejected storage is located on the pod where the specific Output stream is running, under directory /opt/comptel/eventlink/base/status/streams/<streamName>/nodes/VZ_SPS_CFG_ENCODER/rejected/DEFAULT/. The rejected records are stored in sub-directories based on rejection time.

You can examine a file with rejected records by running the following command:

r_export <fileName>

The content of the records is shown in Data Refinery internal format, including the reason for rejection at the end of every rejected record.

Troubleshooting CG Kafka Node

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Node fails on startup due to non-existing Kafka Egress topic

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Make sure that the value set in node parameter EgressTopicName is valid. You should verify also that the topic was created in the Apache Kafka broker.

Run the following command to check the topic existance in Kafka server host:

kafka-topics --list --zookeeper localhost:2181

If your topic is not listed, create it with an adequate number of partitions:

kafka-topics --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 --replication-factor <replication-factor> --partitions <partition-count> --topic <topic-name>

For more information, see Apache Kafka documentation.

Node fails to connect to Kafka broker: Timeout expired while fetching topic metadata

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

This error indicates that an error has occured in the server side of Kafka broker, preventing CG Kafka Node from fetching topics for validation purposes.

First, make sure that Kafka and Zookeeper services are running.

To debug this issue and find the exact failure, you need access to the server side log of the Kafka broker. Usually Kafka logs are located in /etc/kafka/logs.

Rule and message filter administration

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Purpose

This chapter describes the tasks required to author rules and work with message filters in an SPS environment.

Rule, Variable, and Rule system version provisioning

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Rule authoring management

Within an SPS site there is one active rule system at any given time, which contains the rules and variables that are currently in effect. The SPS allows the creation of multiple rule system versions to support having rule systems for different purposes, such as in a lab where different scenarios are being explored, and to maintain previous versions of rule systems as they evolve.
Note: If an RSV is more than 5MB in size, it is not possible to perform an export of the RSV using a Chrome browser. This is a limitation of the browser. Nokia suggests that you use a Mozilla Firefox browser for an operation of this magnitude. To do so, you must change the default setting in Mozilla Firefox, as follows:
  • Navigate to “about:config” in the Firefox address bar.
  • Search for “dom.storage.default_quota”, which is set to 5120 by default.
  • Set the value to 7000 (to export an RSV of 7MB) or an appropriate size that is higher to be able to export the RSV.
The SPS supports a drag and drop editing tree that can be used to associate triggers with one or more rule groups. Triggers are a message type such as Gx CCR or Gy CCA, or AF establishment. Rules and rule variables can be configured using the rule text editors or by importing an existing rule system version. You can re-order rule groups within a trigger or re-order rules within a rule group by dragging the rules up or down. The following options are available to manage an RSV:

  • Edit

    Available when the RSV is in a Draft state. If the RSV is in a Release state, you can revert it to Draft if it has not been distributed to an ME.

  • Delete

    Available when the RSV is in a Draft state. If the RSV is in a Release state, you can revert it to Draft if it has not been distributed to an ME.

  • Import

    To Import Rule Group, tap Add Rule Group, then tap the IMPORT button in the Rule Group window. Add a name for the rule group and browse to find the file to import.

    To reference an existing Rule Group in a different Trigger, select a new Trigger, tap the Add Rule Group button, then tap the REFRENCE RULE GROUP button. Select the name of the rule group and add the new trigger.

  • Export

    Export is supported using the export button that appears in the RSV table when you hover the cursor over a line item in the table. You cannot change the name of the file you are importing in this release.

  • Clone

    Clone is supported using the Clone button that appears in the RSV table when you hover the cursor over a line item in the table. You cannot change the name of the file you are cloning in this release.

  • Distribute to an ME

    The Release version of the RSV is the one that you must distribute to all of the MEs in a Geo-cluster. There is also a SUMMARY button in the Rule Configuration tab. This button opens the RSVs Distribution Status On MEs pop-up that displays lists of ME names, showing the statuses of their associated Activate lists and Distribution lists for Policy or Charging applications.

  • Activate on the ME

    After you have distributed the Release version of the RSV, you must activate it.

When you open the Rules and Variables tab of Policy or the Diameter Rules tab of Diameter Configuration in the SM, you are presented a configurable rule system version form. The Charging application allows you to configure Variables only as the charging rules are configured in the Charging profiles.

When you open the Rule and Variables tab of Policy or the Diameter Rules tab of Diameter Configuration in the SM, there is a filter that allows you to search for any specific RSV by name, state, and last time stamp. Directly under the filter, a list of all RSVs in the application are displayed if you have not used the filter, or a list of all RSVs are displayed for which you have used the filter.

Included in this form, is a button that will allow you to search for, export, and import an RSV, as well as a button that will allow you to add and configure a new RSV.

To create a new RSV, you must:
  1. Provide a name for the RSV.
  2. Provide an application name.
  3. New RSVs are in the draft state automatically; if you need to edit an RSV, ensure the RSV is in a draft state. After it is created you can edit the RSV to change the state to release, and distribute it to the MEs.
  4. Optionally, provide a description.
  5. Optionally, provide a security domain.
  6. Save and Continue.

When you Save and Continue on this form, you are presented with a rules text editor where you can select the triggers, rule groups, or rule variables required for the rules in the new rule system.

The SPS-Charging rules text editor presents triggers and rule variables only.

The Diameter Rules text editor presents triggers and rule groups only.

The trigger must always be selected before carrying on to the rule groups or rule variables configuration forms to populate the Triggers parameter in each of those forms.

The Rules System Version List page provides a list of all the RSVs available as well as an ADD button that can be used to add a new draft version RSV. The Rules System Version form that opens requires that you fill in the parameters as shown in the following table.
Parameter Description Options
Name The name of the RSV in SPS-Charging or SPS-Policy applications. Must be a unique name in the rule system version and it is mandatory. Up to 50 characters only.
State The state of the RSV. Draft, Release, or Active
Application The application of the RSV required.

Policy

Charging

Diameter
Security Domain Select the user types that can see the peer records from the drop-down list in SPS-Charging or SPS-Policy applications. If no value is specified, the records are public —
Description Enter an optional description of the rule system version in SPS-Charging or SPS-Policy applications. —
Trigger Allows selection of a rule set as per the application in SPS-Charging and SPS-Policy applications. Depending on the application, selection of the Trigger (Rule Set) can be made from a list of charging triggers or from a list of policy triggers.
Rule Groups

Allows you to add and configure rules in the rule groups in SPS-Policy applications.

Allows you to select and edit existing rules in the rule group.

Contains an Add New Rule button, if more rules are required.

Rule Group name

Specify if top level rule group

Rule name

Rule logic (if /then statement)
Rule Variables Allows you to add rule variables or select and edit existing rule variables in SPS-Charging and SPS-Policy applications. Add and configure a rule variable.
Note:

There are search filters above the Trigger, Rule Group, and Rule Variables configuration menus that allow you to search for the names of your required Triggers, Rule Groups, and Rule Variables as shown in the following figure.

Rule variables

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

The SPS provides a flexible way to define a variable and set its value based on a flexible logic defined in rules. The rule variable can be used to store values during a rules evaluation and is available to SPS-Policy, SPS-Charging, and SPS-Customer-Engagement to simplify the composition of rule logic.

Rule variables are configurable elements that are unique to a Rule System Version (RSV) under the Rules and Variables tab in Policy or the Variables tab in Charging. They can be configured on SM using either the GUI or north bound API as part of the RSV. Different values can be assigned to a rule variable based on different conditions. After a rule variable is configured, it can be used in the rules of either a rule group or rule set in the same RSV, or in a service profile outside of the RSV by using the related rule variable dictionary attributes. The variable is set based on a rule. One rule variable can also reference another rule variable defined in the same RSV.

A Rule Variable is associated with a trigger and re-initialized every time the Trigger is invoked. The SPS knows which operations and contexts to make available in the GUI according to the trigger and application. Only the source contexts that are applicable to the triggers selected for the rule variable can be used in the rule variable definition.
