In the AAR, this value indicates that the AF requests the PCRF to provide a notification when the resources associated with the corresponding service information are allocated.

Out-of-Credit

Used in the RAR command to indicate when the PCRF reports to the AF that SDFs have run out of credit, and that the termination action indicated by the corresponding Final-Unit-Action AVP applies (3GPP TS 32.240 [23] and 3GPP TS 32.299 [24). The SDFs that are impacted because of the out of credit condition are provided in the Flows AVP. In the AAR, this value indicates that the AF requests the PCRF to provide a notification of SDFs for which credit is no longer available.

Service Information Request

Used in the RAR command to indicate when the server requests the service information from the AF for the bearer event. In the AAR, this value indicates that the AF requests the server to demand service information at each bearer authorization.

Usage Report

In the RA-Request (RAR), this value reports accumulated usage volume when the usage threshold provided by the AF has been reached. In the AA-Request (AAR), this value indicates that the AF requests PCRF to report accumulated usage volume when it reaches the threshold.

SubscriberQosOverrideDirection Specifies the direction for the QoS Override when you configure the override using the Queue and Rate parameters.

Not Set

Indicates that the value field is empty; therefore, there is no value configured.

The following values are available:
  • Egress
  • Ingress
SubscriberQosOverrideFormat Specifies the format of the QoS Override.

Not Set

Indicates that the value field is empty; therefore, there is no value configured.

Custom

When you choose this parameter, the Value parameter is displayed. You can enter a raw string value to configure a custom QoS Override parameter.

Queue

When you choose this parameter, you can configure parameters for a particular queue. The Direction, Queue ID, PIR, CIR, MBS and CBS parameters are displayed.

Rate

When you choose this parameter, you can define an aggregate rate for all queues. The Direction and Rate parameters are displayed.
SubscriberState The Subscriber-State AVP type is Enumerated, and is used to determine the type of identifier that is carried by the Subscription-Id AVP.

Disabled (excl. emergency services)

Used to indicate the subscriber is disabled in the account but emergency services are not.

Enabled

Used to indicate the subscriber is enabled in the account.
SubscriptionIdType The Subscription-Id-Type AVP type is Enumerated, and is used to determine the type of identifier that is carried by the Subscription-Id AVP.

Not Set

Indicates that the value field is empty; therefore, there is no value configured.

End User E.164

International E.164 format (for example, MSISDN), according to the ITU-T E.164 numbering plan defined in [E164] and [CE164].

End User IMSI

IMSI format, according to the ITU-T E.212 numbering plan as defined in [E212] and [CE212].

End User NAI

NAI, as defined in [NAI].

End User Private

Credit-control server private identifier.

End User SIP URI

SIP URI, as defined in [SIP].
TerminateResultCode Used to reject/terminate an unknown subscriber.

Diameter User Unknown

Used when you want to reject/terminate an unknown subscriber with the result code Diameter User Unknown using Session-Command Terminate.
TriggerType The Trigger-Type AVP is of type Enumerated and indicates a single re-authorization event type.

Change in Location

Indicates that a change in the end user location causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Hybrid Subscribed User CSG Information

Indicates a request to report the event that the user enters/leaves a hybrid cell that the user subscribes to. When used in a CCR, at entry to a hybrid cell where the user is a member, the User-CSG-Information AVP is provided with the event report.

Change in Hybrid Unsubscribed User CSG Information

Indicates a request of reporting the event that the user enters/leaves a hybrid cell that the user does not subscribe to. When used in a CCR, at entry to a hybrid cell where the user is not a member, the User-CSG-Information AVP is provided with the event report.

Change in Location Cell Id

Indicates that a change in the Cell Identity where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Location Cell ECGI

Indicates that a change in the ECGI where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Location Cell LAC

Indicates that a change in the LAC where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Location Cell MCC

Indicates that a change in the MCC of the serving network causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota

Change in Location Cell MNC

Indicates that a change in the MNC of the serving network causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Location Cell RAC

Indicates that a change in the RAC where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Location Cell TAC

Indicates that a change in the TAC where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Maximum Bit Rate for Downlink

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated downlink maximum bit rate causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Maximum Bit Rate for Uplink

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated uplink maximum bit rate causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Mean Throughput

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated mean throughput causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Media Composition

Indicates that a change in the media composition (as identified within SDP) for an existing SIP session causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Participants NMB

Used specifically for multi participating sessions to indicate that a change in the number of active participants within a session cause the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Peak Throughput

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated peak throughput shall cause the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Precedence Class

Indicate that a change in the end user negotiated precedence class causes the credit control client to request a re-authorization of the associated quota

Change in QoS

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated QoS causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Delay Class

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated delay class causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Guaranteed Bit Rate for Downlink

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated downlink guaranteed bit rate shall cause the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Guaranteed Bit Rate for Uplink

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated uplink guaranteed bit rate shall cause the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Residual BER

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated residual BER causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS SDU Error Ratio

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated SDU error ratio shall cause the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Traffic Class

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated traffic class causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Traffic Handling Priority

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated traffic handling priority causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in QoS Transfer Delay

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated transfer delay causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in RAT

Indicates that a change in the radio access technology causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Reliability Class

Indicates that a change in the end user negotiated reliability class causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in SGSN IP Address

Indicates that a change in the SGSN IP address causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Service Condition

Indicates that a change in rating conditions associated with a service occurs. The description of the conditions causing a change are service specific and may be documented in middle-tier specifications or may be configurable.

Change in Serving Node

Indicates that a change in serving node causes the credit control client to request re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in Threshold of Participants NMB

Indicate that a change in the threshold of participants number within a session causes the credit control client to request re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in UE Timezone

Indicates that a change in the TimeZone where the end user is located causes the credit control client to request re-authorization of the associated quota.

Change in User CSG Information

Indicates a request of reporting the event that the user enters/leaves a CSG cell. When used in a CCR, at entry to a CSG cell, the User-CSG-Information AVP is provided with the event report.

Change in User Participating Type

Indicates that a change in the user participating type within a session causes the credit control client to ask for a re-authorization of the associated quota.
TunnelType Indicates the type of tunnel to be started.
The supported values are defined in [RFC 2868].
  • Not Set
  • Ascend Tunnel Management Protocol (ATMP)
  • Bay Dial Virtual Services (DVS)
  • Generic Route Encapsulation (GRE)
  • IP Authentication Header in the Tunnel-mode (AH)
  • IP Encapsulating Security Payload in the Tunnel-mode (ESP)
  • IP-in-IP Encapsulation (IP-IP)
  • IP-in-IP Tunneling
  • Layer Two Forwarding (L2F)
  • Layer Two Tunneling Protocol (L2TP)
  • Minimal IP-in-IP Encapsulation (MIN-IP-IP)
  • Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol (PPTP)
  • Reserved
  • Virtual LAN (VLAN)
  • Virtual Tunneling Protocol (VTP)
UserEquipmentInfoType The User-Equipment-Info AVP type is grouped, and allows the credit-control client to indicate the identity and capability of the terminal that the subscriber is using for the connection to network.

Not Set

Indicates that the value field is empty; therefore, there is no value configured.

EU-164

The 64-bit identifier is used to identify the hardware instance of the product, as defined in [EUI64].

IMEISV

The identifier contains the International Mobile Equipment Identifier and Software Version in the international IMEISV format, according to 3GPP TS 23.003 [3GPPIMEI].

MAC

The 48-bit MAC address is formatted, as described in [RAD802.1X].

MEID

The MEID contains a globally unique number that identifies a physical part of CDMA mobile station equipment. The number format is defined by the 3GPP2 report S.R0048.

Modified EU-164

There are a number of types of terminals that have identifiers other than IMEI, IEEE 802 MACs, or EUI-64. The identifiers can be converted to modified EUI-64 format, as described in [IPv6Addr], or by using another method that is referred to in the service-specific documentation.
UserLocationIdentityType The PCEF sends the 3GPP-User-Location-Info AVP to the PCRF by setting the LAC of the CGI/SAI to 0x0000. Applicable only to 3GPP-GPRS and 3GPP-EPS access types.

Not Set

Indicates that the value field is empty; therefore, there is no value configured.

CGI

Indicates the CGI of where the user is registered. CGI is defined in sub-clause 4.3.1 of 3GPP TS 23.003 [2].

ECGI

Indicates the ECGI*. Applicable for E-UTRAN.

RAI

Indicates the RAI of the SGSN where the UE is registered. Not applicable for eHRPD or E-UTRAN.

SAI

Indicates the SAI of where the user is registered. SAI is defined in sub-clause 9.2.3.9 of 3GPP TS 25.413 [7].

TAI

Indicates the TAI. Applicable for E-UTRAN.

Future

Indicates future use.

Event triggers

This section describes the event triggers used in SPS-Policy. The event trigger parameters are described in the following table.
Table 62. Applicable event triggers
Event Trigger R7 GX GPRS R8 Gx Mar R8 Gx Dec R8 Gx Mar GPRS R8 Gx Dec GPRS R8 Gx Mar EPS R8 Gx Dec EPS R9 Gx Dec R9 Gx Dec GPRS R9 Gx Dec EPS R10 Gx Dec R910 Gx Dec GPRS R10 Gx Dec EPS Gx Sandvine
AN GW Change x x x x x x x x
Access Node Gateway Change x x x x x x x x
Default EPS Bearer QoS Change x x x x x x x x
Default EPS Bearer QoS Modification Failure x x x x x x x x x x

Loss of Bearer x x x x x x x x x

Out of Credit x x x x x x x x x x x x x x

User Location Change x x x x x x x x x x
Note: The SPS has predefined default event triggers in the rule set that are defined by 3GPP TS 29.212; however, you can overwrite the default event triggers by defining your own event triggers to meet your requirements. The Event Triggers marked with an asterisk (*) are dynamically added because they are added based on the IP-CAN type, interface type, and device type.

Message filters

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Message filters and routing functions

To support the primary Diameter message routing functions of the SPS, the SPS uses the filter group infrastructure to build conditional rules. This functionality is separate from the Rule engine functionality but uses the same contexts to formulate a condition to provide a flexible framework for Diameter message representation and manipulation.

The message context is a wrapper around a Diameter message and makes the Diameter AVPs for a message type available in the same hierarchical structure as defined in the relevant standards document for the Diameter application.

The SPS uses message filters for base Diameter message validation and application plugin message processing. For a given context, a filter applies a specified action to a message based on a specified attribute.

A context is a source of information and/or a place to apply an action. The most commonly used context for the SPS is the message context, which consists of attributes and actions related to a Diameter message. The SPS also uses the system context which, among other things, contains the system overload state. The SPS creates a separate message-specific context for each supported Diameter message type, including the basic Diameter request and Diameter answer message types.

An attribute is something that can be accessed/read, for example an attribute could be the application type, a command, or AVPs. An action is something that can be invoked. For example, modifying an incoming request before forwarding or populating a response message to send back to the origin host.

A message filter consists of a list of criterion and a list of actions. The criteria are matched against incoming messages. If the message matches all of the criteria, the SPS executes the corresponding action(s) of the message filter. All of the actions of a matching filter are executed. After evaluating one filter, the SPS proceeds to the next filter if applicable. If that filter is deemed to be a match for the incoming messages then the action(s) of that filter are executed.

Message filters are used under the Diameter Configuration icon and under the Subscriber Manager icon of the SM GUI for:
  • Overload protection
  • Throttling
  • Message validation
  • Diameter routing
  • White listing
  • Message tracing

For each application listed above, you can build a filter with the criteria and actions that will be sequentially applied to each message. Filters can be built by adding elements from the menu on the left in the editor.

The options available are dependent on the element that is currently selected. For example, filter criterion can only be added when a filter is selected. You can view the XML source of a message filter by switching to Text mode.

Note that when building a filter, any necessary filter criteria must be placed before the filter action(s) in the GUI or API call. Filters can be dragged up or down to determine the sequence in which they should be evaluated.

When using applications and commands as part of message filter criteria values can be either textual names or numeric values, for example, criteria such as Application = “Gx” or Command = “CCR”. Because a command’s definition is relative to a particular application, command criteria cannot appear without also defining the application criteria in the same message filter.

Building message filters

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Message filter parameters

The SPS uses message filters for base Diameter message validation and application message processing. For a given context, a filter applies a specified action to a message based on a specified attribute.

You can build a filter with the criteria and actions that will be sequentially applied to each message under specific icons in specified applications. Filters can be built by adding elements as they are required in the interface. The options available are dependent on the element that’s currently selected. For example, filter criterion can only be added when a filter is selected.

Note that when building a filter, any necessary filter criteria must be placed before the filter action(s) in the GUI or API call. Filters can be dragged up or down to determine the sequence in which they should be evaluated.

Every profile form in the GUI using message filters displays only the basic options applicable for the profile.

The list of criteria and actions displayed in the drop-down varies with respect to the profile, for example, in a routing profile the criteria Diameter Request lists the action Route-To-Chosen-Peer, whereas in message validation profile it lists the action Perform-Base-Validation. To view advanced options for message filters, click the View More Options check-box to re-load the profile GUI with more options.

When using applications and commands as part of message filter criteria values, you can have either textual names or numeric values, for example, criteria such as Application = “Gx” or Command = “CCR”. Because a command’s definition is relative to a particular application, command criteria cannot appear without also defining the application criteria in the same message filter. Auto suggest can always be used for choosing attributes in the Add Message Filter configuration panels.

The following tables describe the parameters for filter groups, filters, criterion, and action.

Table 63. Filter group
Field Description
name The name of the filter group
filter The list of filter(s) defined for the filter group
Table 64. Filter
Field Description
Filter Name The name of the message filter
Filter Criterion An ordered collection of zero or more filter attribute criterion that allows you to select the message type, attribute with an operator, a value, and another operator if required. You can add a list of criterion for the message.
Filter Actions An ordered collection of one or more filter actions that allows you to select the message type, action attribute with an operator, and a value.
Table 65. Filter criterion
Field Description
name The name of the attribute
context The name of the context in which this attribute resides
operator

The following operators can be added from the drop down list.

PRESENT

NOT_PRESENT

EQUAL

NOT_EQUAL

GREATER_THAN

LESS_THAN

GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL

LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL

CONTAINS

DOES_NOT_CONTAIN

MATCH_PATTERN

DOES_NOT_MATCH_PATTERN

CASE_INSENSITIVE_EQUAL

CASE_INSENSITIVE_NOT_EQUAL

CASE_INSENSITIVE_MATCH_PATTERN

CASE_INSENSITIVE_DOES_NOT_MATCH_ PATTERN

The list of available operators is determined by the data type of attribute.

Attribute value The value(s) the attribute must match to trigger the associated action. (Optional)
Parameter Name and Value For parameterized actions, the parameter. names and values (Optional)
Table 66. Filter action
Field Description
name The name of the filter action
context The name of the context in which the action resides
Parameter Name and Value

For parameterized actions, the parameter names and values

Optional

Rule dictionaries and definitions across SM and MEs

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

The custom rule dictionary, along with the attribute definition, and custom vendor definition files must be copied to all SM and/or ME applications. This includes custom rule dictionaries for Charging, Policy, and SM.

You must perform both of the following procedures, one after the other:
  • Installing the custom rule dictionary
  • To install, copy, and distribute the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files

The SPS also supports the use of an unlimited number of VSA dictionary files and the Attribute definition dictionaries. The VSA files can be used across all Diameter interfaces. Each dictionary defines the list of valid attributes that are supported by the vendor and are available for SPS-Policy and SPS-Charging management. The dictionaries must be on the SPS workstation to be loaded. You add a VSA to a vendor dictionary to add the VSA to the SPS. To display the VSA in the GUI or to use it in rules, you must also add the VSA to the VsaToContextMapping.xml file in the respective contexts.

If you are adding VSAs, see "Adding VSAs".

Adding VSAs

The workflow to create or modify a dictionary is as follows:
  • create an entry in the CustomVendorDefinition.xml for the vendor
  • create a dictionary by name and specify all of the VSAs in the VsaToContextMapping.xml file
  • reload all of the VSA dictionaries to load the changes
  • distribute the files to all of the nodes
To add or modify attributes, you need to create a dictionary and add or modify the attributes (see “To add to the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files”) in the dictionary in the opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter directory. You can add a VSA dictionary file to the SPS at any time. The format of the file is:
/opt/tpa/schemas/DiameterDefinition.xsd

To display the VSA in the SPS rule engine, the GUI, or to be able to use the VSA in rules for Policy or Charging, you must also add the VSA to the VsaToContextMapping.xml in the respective files and contexts. That is, a VSA entry must be present in a dictionary and a source and/or result context mapping must be in the VSA mapping file.

To use a VSA on specific interfaces only, the VsaRuleSourceContext and VsaRuleResultContext must be mapped to the VSA. When the context is mapped to the VSA, the VSA is only available as a criteria or an action along with the configured contexts.

To configure VSA entries in a dictionary, use the VsaToContextMapping.xml file. The VsaToContextMapping.xml file provides an xml document that can be modified to include the individual VSA definitions.

The VsaToContextMapping.xml file for Policy is located in:
/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/rule/VsaToContextMapping.xml
The VsaToContextMapping.xml file for Charging is located in:
/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/rule/ChargingVsaToContextMapping.xml
Copy the contents of the VSA mapping file and enter the required values for the VSAs you are adding, as follows:
<diameterToRuleContextMap xmlns="diameterRuleContextMap">
<vsaToContext>
<vsaToRuleSourceContexts>
<vsaRuleSourceContext>
<context type="CONTEXT"/>
<vendorInfo>
<name>vendorname</name>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA”/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA2” maxOccurs="unbounded"
additive="true"/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA3” valueType=
"EnumValueType" valueTypeClassName="com.alcatel.tpapps.diameter.par.
EventTrigger"/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA4.attribute-VSA5”
includeGroupIndexArgs="true"/>
</vendorInfo>
</vsaRuleSourceContext>
</vsaToRuleSourceContexts>
<vsaToRuleResultContexts>
<vsaRuleResultContext>
<context type="CONTEXT"/>
<vendorInfo>
<name>vendorname</name>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA”/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA2” maxOccurs="unbounded"
additive="true"/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA3” valueType=
"EnumValueType" valueTypeClassName="com.alcatel.tpapps.diameter.par.
EventTrigger"/>
<includeAttribute name=”attribute-VSA4.attribute-VSA5”
includeGroupIndexArgs="true"/>
</vendorInfo>
</vsaRuleResultContext>
</vsaToRuleResultContext>
</vsaToContext>
</diameterToRuleContextMap>

Save and add the file back to the respective directory.

Perform “To install, copy, and distribute the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files” to copy and distribute the VSA mapping file, the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files.

To install, copy, and distribute the custom rule attribute dictionary
  1. Obtain the CustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml files that you need from the appropriate repository location provided by Nokia (for example, the PCRFCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml, ChargingCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml, diameter/rule/ChargingVsaToContextMapping.xml, diameter/rule/VsaToContextMapping.xml or RSCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml).
  2. Connect to the SM active OAME as the root user.
  3. Put the file obtained in step 1 in a directory of your choice on the SM’s Active OAME.
    Note: Before copying any files to any SPS VMs, the user must execute the df and du Linux commands from each VM to determine the storage available and whether or not the copying of new files can proceed. Usage of the Linux commands df (abbreviation for disk free) and du (abbreviated from disk usage) can be found on every VM via the Linux manual page by using “man df” and “man du” as root user. There are two storage directories that can be used on any VM as follows:
    • First choice, is under the /appdata directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM.
    • Second choice, is under the /var/log directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM. If there is enough storage available, proceed. When you have completed the task, clean-up the files that are no longer needed. If there is not enough space, either do some clean-up or contact Nokia Support.
  4. If you are installing a new PCRFCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml file, a new ChargingCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml, diameter/rule/ ChargingVsaToContextMapping.xml, diameter/rule/VsaToContextMapping.xml or a new RSCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml run the following command on the SM’s Active OAME:
    /opt/tpa/bin/distribute-rules-dictionaries -d <directory> [-e <MEs>]
[-i <MEs>]
    Where:
    Option Description
    -d <directory> Source directory containing the custom rules attribute dictionary files to distribute. This is not required when run on an ME to distribute files that came from an SM.
    -e <MEs> Excludes the MEs (comma-separated OAME VIPs of MEs) from distribution. Only meaningful when run on SM.
    -i <MEs> Includes the MEs (comma-separated OAME VIPs of MEs) for distribution. Only meaningful when run on SM.
    -h Displays help for this tool.
    The command performs the following:
    • Pushes the dictionary files to the SM application nodes in that SM site.
    • Reloads rules in all the SM app nodes.
    • Creates an archive of the dictionary files and pushes it to the Active OAME node on the ME sites.
  5. For the PCRFCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml file, ChargingCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml, diameter/rule/ ChargingVsaToContextMapping.xml, diameter/rule/VsaToContextMapping.xml or RSCustomRuleAttributeDictionary.xml run the following command on each ME's Active OAME:
    /opt/tpa/bin/distribute-rules-dictionaries
    The command performs the following:
    • Extracts the archive already transferred from the SM.
    • Pushes the dictionary files to the Diameter applications and Common Services nodes in the ME site.
    • Reloads the rules in all the applicable nodes.

To add to the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files

Use this procedure to add VSAs and vendor definitions to the attribute definition, and custom vendor definition files. Both the AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml exist in “/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa” on all SM, ME IOHD, Comservice, and Diameter nodes. Other definition files can also exist in the directory as you require them for your configuration and can be distributed in the same manner.
  1. Connect to the SM active OAME as the root user.
  2. Open the AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml files that you need from the “/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa” directory using a text editor. The following files are sample files that are installed by default.
    • /opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa/AttributeDefinitionTemplate.xml
    • /opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa/CustomVendorDefinition.xml
  3. To add or modify a dictionary file, define the vendor_name and vendor_id in the CustomVendorDefinition.xml file to notify the system that the vendor is valid and supported by the SPS. For example, to add Motorola, type: 
    <vendor id=”161” name=”MOT”/>
  4. Save and close the CustomVendorDefinition.xml file.
  5. Open or create a vendor dictionary file to add or modify attributes. Use the following format for the filename: AttributeDefinition.xml; for example,
    AttributeDefinitionTemplate.xml
    You can modify all of the parameters in the .xml file, which are described in the following table. The AttributeDefinition<VENDOR_NAME>.xml file defines a list of VSAs. Each vendor has a separate file.
    Parameter Description
    attribute code Integer assigned to the attribute by the vendor
    <vendorName> Each vendor has a unique vendor ID.
    <name> Name of the attribute
    <format> The Diameter AVP format
    <mFlag> Determines whether AVP support is mandatory. The options are:
    • REQUIRED*
    • OPTIONAL
    • FORBIDDEN
    Must be set to REQUIRED; otherwise, the VSA is not loaded.
    <pFlag> Determines whether end-to-end encryption is required. The options are:
    • REQUIRED
    • OPTIONAL
    • FORBIDDEN
    <vFlag> Any attribute that is a VSA and is added to a vendor dictionary must specify REQUIRED for the in its definition; otherwise, the VSA is not loaded.
    • REQUIRED
    • OPTIONAL
    • FORBIDDEN
    This restriction does not apply to standard attributes.
    <encrypt> The type of encryption used to encrypt and decrypt the attribute. The options are:
    • True to encrypt
    • False otherwise
    <register> Determines whether the Diameter AVP definition should be registered. The options are:
    • True (to register)
    • False otherwise
    <proprietary> Determines whether the dictionary is proprietary. The options are:
    • True (VSA, proprietary)
    • False (standard non-proprietary)
  6. Perform “To install, copy, and distribute the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files” to copy and distribute the VsaToContextMapping.xml, attribute definition, and custom vendor definition files.

To install, copy, and distribute the attribute definition and custom vendor definition files

Use this CLI tool in the OAME to install, copy, and distribute the attribute definition, and custom vendor definition files, along with the VSA mapping file from the OAME to the SMs and MEs. Both the AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml exist in “/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa” on all ME IOHD, Comservice, and Diameter nodes. Other definition files can also exist in the directory as you require them for your configuration and can be distributed in the same manner.
  1. If this is an installation, obtain the VsaToContextMapping.xml, AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml files that you need from the appropriate repository location provided by Nokia.
  2. Connect to the SM active OAME as the root user.
  3. Put the files obtained in step 1 in a directory of your choice on the SM’s Active OAME. If you have added to the VsaToContextMapping.xml, AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml files that already exist in the “/opt/tpa/conf/sac/diameter/vsa” directory, go to the next step.
    Note: Before copying any files to any SPS VMs, the user must execute the df and du Linux commands from each VM to determine the storage available and whether or not the copying of new files can proceed. Usage of the Linux commands df (abbreviation for disk free) and du (abbreviated from disk usage) can be found on every VM via the Linux manual page by using “man df” and “man du” as root user. There are two storage directories that can be used on any VM as follows:
    • First choice, is under the /appdata directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM.
    • Second choice, is under the /var/log directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM. If there is enough storage available, proceed. When you have completed the task, clean-up the files that are no longer needed. If there is not enough space, either do some clean-up or contact Nokia Support.
      /opt/tpa/bin/distribute-diameter-dictionaries -d <directory>
      Where the is the directory containing the VsaToContextMapping.xml, AttributeDefinition.xml and CustomVendorDefinition.xml files. The command performs the following:
      • Pushes the dictionary files to the SM application nodes in that SM site.
      • Reloads rules in all the SM app nodes.
      • Creates an archive of the dictionary files and pushes it to the Active OAME node on the ME sites.
  4. Run the following command on each ME's Active OAME:
    /opt/tpa/bin/distribute-diameter-dictionaries
    The command performs the following:
    • Extracts the archive already transferred from the SM.
    • Pushes the dictionary files to the Diameter applications and Common Services nodes in the ME site.
    • Reloads the rules in all the applicable nodes.

Troubleshooting

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Changing the logging levels of SPS functions

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

This procedure is for changing the logging levels for the Java application and is not applicable to the database, CDR, or any /var/log/. Perform this procedure to modify the logging level of one or more SPS functions for troubleshooting purposes. See “Changing SPS logging levels”for information about the logging levels.
Note:

Lowering a logging level creates additional log entries and requires more system resources, which can affect system performance. Ensure that you lower the logging level for only the required functions and for only the time required to collect the troubleshooting information.

For day-to-day operations, be sure to review the aggregated logs in the AdminCLI /var/log/ directory rather than the logs on each node in the /opt/tpa/log/ directory.

Modifications to the /opt/tpa/logs/log4j.xml file are not automatically carried over during an upgrade. If you modify the log4j.xml file, after an upgrade you must manually merge your changes from the previous /opt//logs/log4j.xml file to the new /opt/ /logs/log4j.xml file.

Application logs INFO level and lower are sent to the OAM from the application nodes.

Steps

  1. Open a console window and log in as tpaadmin to the specific node where you want to modify the log level.
  2. Open the log4j.xml file in /opt/tpa/logs/ directory using a text editor.
  3. Perform any of the following:
    • To change the logging level for general SPS functions, replace logging_level in the following with the logging level that you need, for example, DEBUG.
      <logger name="com.nokia.tpapps.">
<level value="logging_level"/>
</logger>
    • To change the logging level for the Diameter protocol, replace logging_level in the following with the logging level that you need, for example, DEBUG.
      <logger name="com.nokia.tpapps.diameter">
<level value="logging_level"/>
</logger>
    • Restart the application server after modifying log4j.xml.
    • Save and close the log4j.xml file.

Jaeger

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Jaeger is a distributed tracing platform which leverages OpenTracing to deliver analytics and visualizations regarding system performance. For more information, see the Jaeger documentation portal.

Accessing the Jaeger console

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia
To access the Jaeger console, navigate to the following link in a web browser:
https://<sps_server_ip>:<jaeger_port>
Where:
  • <sps_server_ip> is the address for the SPS server.
  • <jaeger_port> is the port on which the Jaeger console is running.

Jaeger configurations in the values.yaml

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Overview

Jaeger configurations may be made in the values.yaml file as part of the OpenTracing configurations.

The following is an example of the OpenTracing and Jaeger configurations in the values.yaml.
opentracing:
    headers: "x-request-id,x-b3-traceid,x-b3-spanid,x-b3-parentspanid,x-b3-sampled,x-b3-flags,b3"
    jaeger:
      endpoint: "http://jaeger-collector.istio-system.svc.cluster.local:14268/api/traces"

Header configuration

In the values.yaml, the headers property can be used to configure which headers are propagated.
opentracing:
    header: <your_headers_here>

Where <your_headers_here> is a comma separated list of headers to propagate.

For example, the following is configured to propagate headers x-request-id, x-b3-traceid, x-b3-spanid, x-b3-parentspanid, x-b3-sampled, x-b3-flags, and b3.
opentracing:
    headers: "x-request-id,x-b3-traceid,x-b3-spanid,x-b3-parentspanid,x-b3-sampled,x-b3-flags,b3"

Endpoint configuration

In the values.yaml, the endpoint property can be used to configure endpoints, which tell Jaeger where to send traces collected in SPS.
opentracing:
    headers: "x-request-id,x-b3-traceid,x-b3-spanid,x-b3-parentspanid,x-b3-sampled,x-b3-flags,b3"
    jaeger:
      endpoint: <endpoint_address>

Where <endpoint_address> is the address of the endpoint to which Jaeger will send traces.

For example, the following is configuration sends traces to the endpoint at http://jaeger-collector.istio-system.svc.cluster.local:14268/api/traces.
opentracing:
    headers: "x-request-id,x-b3-traceid,x-b3-spanid,x-b3-parentspanid,x-b3-sampled,x-b3-flags,b3"
    jaeger:
      endpoint: "http://jaeger-collector.istio-system.svc.cluster.local:14268/api/traces"

SPS tools

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

This appendix describes the tools that are available outside of the Service Manager GUI. Although most provisioning and configuration is done using the Service Manager GUI, the SPS also features tools for other specific tasks.

SPS database is managed using a series of command line tools. The tools may be run by the customer or by the Nokia support personnel. The tools are provided on the AdminCLI pod, a singleton pod specifically for this purpose. A kubectl command will be run by users to gain access to the AdminCLI pod for running these SPS tools and scripts.

Supported tools

The following tools are supported:
  • configure-manual-oos: manually declares a component that is in a geo-redundant deployment out of service.
  • db-backup: creates a backup of the Aerospike database
  • db-list: lists the records in the Aerospike database, which is written in a compressed (.gz) files in a JSON format.
  • db-stats: displays Aerospike database statistics
  • log-level: provides get/set/reset log levels from the AdminCLI pod to all application servers in the cluster.
  • network-heartbeat: retrieves the heartbeat status on demand.
  • sps-status: displays status information for this SPS system.
  • xdr-status:

configure-manual-oos

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Description

This command is run as the root user or tpaadmin from /opt/tpa/bin and used to manually declare a component that is in a geo-redundant deployment out of service. It can set and clear the manual out of service flag for a component (stored in SDC).

When a site is set OOS using configure-manual-oos:
  • other sites in the geo-redundant configuration see this site as Out-Of-Service (SMs and MEs), until it is returned to service using configure-manual-oos -e <component name>
  • there is a system wide graceful shutdown of all Diameter links (Client or SPS Initiated)
  • provisioning operations cannot be executed on the OOS site (SM or ME), until it is returned to service

Syntax

configure-manual-oos [-d] [-e] [-h] [-s]
Note: The component name is case sensitive and must be entered as upper case ME or SM. For example:
configure-manual-oos -d ME
Code Description
-d <component name> Declares the component manually out of service.
-e <component name> Clear the component from being declared manually out of service.
-h or -? Displays usage/help information.
-s Print each component name and whether or not it is manually out of service.
Note: When this command is run on a non-Geo SPS, it will do nothing but “Component ME State: UP” will be displayed when running the “sps-status” tool.
Note: This command is supported on an IG but requires that you state SM or ME to render the respective functionality on the IG OOS.

Examples

The following is an example of the output that you will receive from the configure-manual-oos -d ME command. The -s command accompanying the -d command prints each component name and whether or not it is out of service.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -d ME
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
ME: TRUE
The following is an example of the output that you will receive from the configure-manual-oos -e ME command. The -s command accompanying the -e command prints each component name and whether or not it is out of service.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -e ME
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
ME: FALSE
The following is an example of the output that you will receive from the configure-manual-oos -d SM command. The -s command accompanying the -d command prints each component name and whether or not it is out of service.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -d SM
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
SM: TRUE
The following is an example of the output that you will receive from the configure-manual-oos -e SM command. The -s command accompanying the -e command prints each component name and whether or not it is out of service.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -e SM
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
SM: FALSE

Usage examples of output from the ME

In this example, the site’s initial status according to configure-manual-oos, sps-status and network-heartbeat is displayed for an ME. Then the same is displayed when the site is taken out-of-service (OOS). Finally, we show the OOS cleared on the site.

Output similar to the following is expected when you run configure-manual-oos -s on an ME that is running with all services UP in a geo-redundant deployment.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
ME: FALSE
If you run the sps-status command after running the configure-manual-oos -s command, you will confirm the ME component is UP and the services that are UP by the output of the sps-status command:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# sps-status
Software Version: SPS_18_7_R1 (SPS_18_7_I335)
Date: Tue Jul 24 13:23:21 EDT 2018
Site Name: SPS-ME-1-SCTP-SPS_18_7_I335
Component ME State: UP
----------------------------------------------------------
Service State Vital Mode Instances
----------------------------------------------------------
ROLLBACK UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-admincli-0: UP (STANDBY)
sps-me-1-admincli-1: UP (ACTIVE)
CDR UP true NPLUSK sps-me-1-cdr-0: UP
sps-me-1-cdr-1: UP
LOADBALANCER UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-ioho-0: UP (ACTIVE)
sps-me-1-ioho-1: UP (STANDBY)
LTM UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-admincli-0: UP (STANDBY)
sps-me-1-admincli-1: UP (ACTIVE)
DIAMETERIO UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-iohd-0: UP (ACTIVE)
sps-me-1-iohd-1: UP (STANDBY)
AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER UP true STANDALONE
XDR UP true STANDALONE
CHARGING UP true NPLUSK sps-me-1-diameterapp-0: UP
sps-me-1-diameterapp-1: UP
RECOMMENDATION UP false NPLUSK sps-me-1-comsvc-0: UP
sps-me-1-comsvc-1: UP
PROVISIONING UP false NPLUSK sps-me-1-comsvc-0: UP
sps-me-1-comsvc-1: UP
TEM UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-admincli-0: UP (STANDBY)
sps-me-1-admincli-1: UP (ACTIVE)
POLICY UP true NPLUSK sps-me-1-diameterapp-0: UP
sps-me-1-diameterapp-1: UP
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Service state queried from 'sps-me-1-admincli-1'.
If you run the network-heartbeat script on this ME, you will get output similar to the following:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# network-heartbeat
Local Status:
Component [ME] Service Status [IN_SERVICE]
Status for Site 'sps-me-2' ID [2] Component [ME] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [0] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]
Status for Site 'sps-sm-6' ID [6] Component [SM] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]
Status for Site 'sps-me-3' ID [3] Component [ME] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [0] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]
Status for Site 'sps-sm-5' ID [5] Component [SM] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]
No alarm.
When you manually set this ME to Out-Of-Service and list the running MEs, using configure-manual-oos and display the site’s status according to configure-manual-oos, sps-status, and network-heartbeat, you have output similar to the following:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -d ME
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
ME: TRUE
After running the configure-manual-oos -s command and from the sps-status command, you will confirm the ME component is DOWN and services that are UP as follows:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# sps-status
Software Version: SPS_18_7_R1 (SPS_18_7_I335)

Site Name: SPS-ME-1-SCTP-SPS_18_7_I335
Component ME State: DOWN
----------------------------------------------------------

----------------------------------------------------------

sps-me-1-cdr-1: UP

sps-me-1-ioho-1: UP (STANDBY)
LTM UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-admincli-0: UP (STANDBY)
sps-me-1-admincli-1: UP (ACTIVE)
DIAMETERIO UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-iohd-0: UP (ACTIVE)
sps-me-1-iohd-1: UP (STANDBY)
AEROSPIKE_CLUSTER UP true STANDALONE
XDR UP true STANDALONE

sps-me-1-diameterapp-1: UP

sps-me-1-comsvc-1: UP
PROVISIONING UP false NPLUSK sps-me-1-comsvc-0: UP
sps-me-1-comsvc-1: UP
TEM UP true ONEPLUSONE sps-me-1-admincli-0: UP (STANDBY)
sps-me-1-admincli-1: UP (ACTIVE)
POLICY UP true NPLUSK sps-me-1-diameterapp-0: UP
sps-me-1-diameterapp-1: UP
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Service state queried from 'sps-me-1-admincli-1'.
If you run the network-heartbeat script on this ME, you will get output similar to the following:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# network-heartbeat
Local Status:
Component [ME] Service Status [OUT_OF_SERVICE]
Status for Site 'sps-me-2' ID [2] Component [ME] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [0] Last contact
[0s ago] Last attempt [0s ago]

[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[0s ago] Last attempt [0s ago]

[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [0] Last contact
[0s ago] Last attempt [0s ago]
Status for Site 'sps-sm-5' ID [5] Component [SM] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[0s ago] Last attempt [0s ago]
In the final part of this example, the manual OOS state is cleared from the applicable component on the site using configure-manual-oos and then we display the site’s status according to configure-manual-oos, sps-status, and network-heartbeat.
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -e ME
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# configure-manual-oos -s
------------------
COMPONENT | MOOS
------------------
ME: FALSE
Then verify with sps-status:
[root@sps-me-1-admincli-1 ~]# sps-status
Software Version: SPS_18_7_R1 (SPS_18_7_I335)

The following is an example of the output that you will receive from the configure-manual-oos -d SM command. The -s command accompanying the -d command prints each component name and whether or not it is out of service.

------------------

When you run the sps-status command, the status of the services are given for the services associated with the SM. When you run the network-heartbeat command, the heartbeat statuses of both the SM and the MEs associated with the SM are output. For example:
[root@sps-sm-6-admincli-0 ~]# network-heartbeat Local Status:
Component [SM] Service Status [OUT_OF_SERVICE]
Status for Site 'sps-sm-5' ID [5] Component [SM] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]
Status for Site 'sps-me-2' ID [2] Component [ME] Service status
[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]

[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]

[IN_SERVICE] Missed OAM beats [0] Missed traffic beats [N/A] Last contact
[1s ago] Last attempt [1s ago]

db-backup

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Description

This tool creates a backup copy of the Aerospike database so that it may be restored later if there are unforeseen situations (such as DB corruption or other severe scenarios) whereby the database needs to be restored back to a previous version.

Nightly backups can be achieved by scheduling db-backup to run on a scheduled interval (for example, each night during the maintenance window).

This tool is run on the active AdminCLI pod in the SPS system. Unless you are doing a disaster recovery, Nokia recommends that you perform this procedure during off hours (non-peak-hours). A separate backup file will be created for each namespace, with inline compression (gzip) performed as the file is created to reduce the amount of disk space required for these backups. All namespaces and data sets will be backed up.
Note: db-backup will terminate if the cluster changes during the backup (for example, if a node goes down )
Note: Do not run this command during the transition window from daylight saving time to standard time.

Syntax

db-backup -d <directory> -n <namespace[,namespace]*> [-f] [-r
<local|both|all>]
Code Description
No arguments Displays usage/help information.
-h or -? Displays usage/help information.
-d <directory> Output directory for the backup files. This directory should already exist.
-f Force execution. If specified, the user will not be asked for confirmation.
-n <namespace[,namespace]*> Namespace list to backup. Allows you to specify the namespaces to backup.
-r Nodes running and storing the backups..

Example

A summary output for this command using the “-r” option is provided to the user. Details of the backup operation can be found in the backuplog file, in the specified backup directory.
[tpaadmin@sps-me-1-admincli-0 ~]$ db-backup -d /BACKUP/20190322 -r all
15:13 db-backup issued at: Fri Mar 22 15:13:36 EDT 2020
15:13
15:13 Creating a database backup to [/BACKUP/20190322]
This action will create a backup of the local database in the directory:
/BACKUP/20190322
ATTENTION: The original database backup file will be removed if it
exists.
Do you wish to continue? (y/n)y
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-0 for sps-me-1-db-0-dsc
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-1 for sps-me-1-db-1-dsc
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-2 for sps-me-1-db-2-dsc
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-3 for sps-me-1-db-3-dsc
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-0-dsc completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-2-dsc completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-3-dsc completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-1-dsc completed
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-0 for sps-me-1-db-0-dsclocal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-1 for sps-me-1-db-1-dsclocal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-2 for sps-me-1-db-2-dsclocal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-3 for sps-me-1-db-3-dsclocal
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-0-dsclocal completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-2-dsclocal completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-1-dsclocal completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-3-dsclocal completed
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-0 for sps-me-1-db-0-dscglobal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-1 for sps-me-1-db-1-dscglobal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-2 for sps-me-1-db-2-dscglobal
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-3 for sps-me-1-db-3-dscglobal
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-1-dscglobal completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-2-dscglobal completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-0-dscglobal completed
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-0 for sps-me-1-db-0-spspd1
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-1 for sps-me-1-db-1-spspd1
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-2 for sps-me-1-db-2-spspd1
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-3-dscglobal completed
15:13 Starting backup on sps-me-1-db-3 for sps-me-1-db-3-spspd1
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-1-spspd1 completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-0-spspd1 completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-2-spspd1 completed
15:13 Backup for sps-me-1-db-3-spspd1 completed
15:13
15:13 sps-me-1-db-0
15:13 dsc Completed
15:13 dsclocal Completed
15:13 dscglobal Completed
15:13 spspd1 Completed
15:13 sps-me-1-db-1
15:13 dsc Completed
15:13 dsclocal Completed
15:13 dscglobal Completed
15:13 spspd1 Completed
15:13 sps-me-1-db-2
15:13 dsc Completed
15:13 dsclocal Completed
15:13 dscglobal Completed
15:13 spspd1 Completed
15:13 sps-me-1-db-3
15:13 dsc Completed
15:13 dsclocal Completed
15:13 dscglobal Completed
15:13 spspd1 Completed
15:14
15:14 SPS DB backup completed into directory [/BACKUP/20190322]
15:14 on the database nodes.
15:14
15:14 See [/BACKUP/20190322/DB_BACKUP_*/*.backuplog] for
15:14 detailed output of backup command execution.
15:14
15:14 db-backup completed at: Fri Mar 22 15:14:02 EDT 2020

db-list

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Description

The db-list tool lists the records in the Aerospike database and the listing is written into compressed (.gz) files in a JSON format.

Following guidelines are applied for the usage of the tool:
  • This tool is relevant to the ME only. Any data that the tool is meant to dump is not present on the SM.

  • The db-list tool is installed only on the AdminCLI pod. Nokia recommends you to run the db-list tool only in low business or low traffic hours.

  • Only one instance of the db-list tool can be executed at a given time. The tool cannot be executed in case a similar tool (for example, db-backup, db-restore, asbackup, or asrestore tool) is currently running on the AdminCLI pod.

    Nokia recommends to ensure that the db-list tool or any other similar tool is not concurrently running on other nodes.

  • The data is spread over two Aerospike sets related by a club-id.

    Nokia recommends you to use the db-list tool when database updates in the system are minimum and the database updates happen due to activities like provisioning, on-call traffic, or audit are minimum. Once the db-list tool has been started for execution for a specific set and that set fetches objects from another set, the time elapsed between fetching information from these two sets might lead to inconsistent data.

    For instance, to dump all data related to a device, the device is read from one set and then its custom data, aggregate view instances, and bucket instances among others are read from different set. If it takes x amount of time (usually in milliseconds for each entity) to dump the same data then, for instance, if any provisioning activity or 4G or 5G call or audit are ongoing during the same time frame then data dumped might be inconsistent. The case may arise where subscription id is read from device data and by the time tool tries to read the subscription object, it may already have been deleted from the database due to any activity mentioned above.

  • The db-list tool always starts from the beginning and there is no option to pause or resume a previous tool invocation. This means that, if the db-list tool is interrupted due to any reason or exception, then when the tool is executed next time, it starts from the beginning. The data files created before interruption needs to be manually deleted from the system.
  • Edigest is dumped with each <entity> option.
    Note: Edigest is a primary key that uniquely identifies a record in the Aerospike database within a given namespace. Primary key is used in application, while the digest is used for addressing the record in the database.
  • In order to dump all policy and charging sessions, run the db-list tool separately for all policy and charging sessions.
    ./db-list -l policysessions
./db-list -l chargingsessions
  • In case of dump taken from a system having a larger data size provisioned, for example millions of devices with all associated charging data, then the following options in db-list tool are helpful:
    • t : number of threads
    • q : worker queue capacity (it is fixed to 100k records at present)
    • r : JVM heap size (it is 2G at present)
    For more information, see the Troubleshooting appendix of this guide.

Syntax

Log into the standby AdminCLI pod as the tpaadmin user and type the db-list command:
db-list [-l <entity>] [-s <primary|all>] [-n <namespace>] [-m <max>] [-o
<dir>]

None of the options mentioned in this command are mandatory.

The tool can be launched without any options. If this occurs, then it uses the default value for each option.

Options Description Option arguments
No arguments Displays usage or help information. —
-h or -? Displays usage or help information. —
-l <entity> Displays the type of entity for which you need records listed. Only one entity at a time can be added in this argument. For example, -l <devices>

Default value of this option is -l devices.

The -l <entity> option of the db-list tool has the following output:

  • -l devices: Lists the devices in the InfrequentlyChangingData set along with the custom data, device subscriptions, subscription counter, associated bucket instances, threshold instances, account balance data, cap instances, device counters, Aggregate View (AV), and DPU present in the DynamicData set.

    Edigest is present for device, custom data, subscription, subscription counter, device counter, AV instance, DPU, account balance, and for bucket instance at CS level.

  • -l accounts: Lists the accounts along with the account administrator present in InfrequentlyChangingData and custom data attributes of the account present in the DynamicData set.

  • -l users: Lists the users along with the custom data attributes of the user present in the InfrequentlyChangingData and DynamicData set respectively.

    Edigest is present for user and custom data associated with account.

  • -l groups: Lists the groups in the InfrequentlyChangingData set along with the custom data, group subscriptions, associated bucket instances, subscription counter, threshold instances, cap instances, group and device_group counters, aggregate view, and account balance data present in the DynamicData set.

    Edigest is present for group, custom data, subscription, subscription counter, group counter, AV instance, device group counter, account balance, and for bucket instance at CS level.

  • -l sysessions: Lists only the sessions of Sy type present in the SessionContainer set.

  • -l afsessions: Lists only the sessions of Af type present in the SessionContainer set.

  • -l ucs: Lists all the records present in the UsageControlService set.

  • -l allsubscriberdata: Lists all the subscriber entities data (which includes, devices, groups, users, and accounts).

  • -l gysessions: Lists all the Gy sessions present in the DynamicData set.

  • -l imssessions: Lists all the IMS sessions present in the DynamicData set.

  • -l ratingsessions: Lists all the rating sessions present in the DynamicData set.

  • -l chargingsysessions: Lists all the Sy sessions present in the DynamicData set.

  • -l chargingsessions: Lists all the charging sessions (Gy, rating, IMS, and Sy) present in the DynamicData set.
-s <primary|all>

The primary option lists only the records that are primary to this site and the all option lists all devices.

This option is applicable only when the listed object is one of devices, accounts, users, or groups. This option is ignored if the value is not one of the values for devices, accounts, users, or groups.

 Default value is primary. Lists primary or all
-n <namespace|all> The Aerospike namespace to look in for the records.

Default value is all.

The namespace should be a partitioned namespace. For example, the namespaces starting with the spspd prefix.

If all is specified, then the tool lists from all the partitioned namespaces.
-m <max|all> The maximum number of records to be listed.

Default value is all.

If all is specified, then the tool does not stop until it has processed all of the records.
-o <dir>

The output directory where the listed records are placed.

In the specified directory, the tool creates a new directory bearing the name of the selected object type and the current timestamp.
  • Ensure that you have sufficient disk space in the file system mount where the output directory is located.
  • Ensure that the user used to execute the tool has write permissions on the specified output directory.
 Default value is /opt/tpa/logs/.
-t <nThreads> Displays the number of processing threads.

Default value is equal to half the number of CPUs or VCPUs on the node.

A high number of processing threads increase the CPU utilization of the node. On the other hand, a lower processing thread count may engage Aerospike query threads for longer durations.

Nokia recommends you to select the number of processing threads nearest to the number of CPUs.
-f <nFiles> Displays the number of out files.

Default value is equal to the number of processing threads.

Nokia recommends you to keep the number of out files the same as the number of processing threads.

-q <nCapacity> Displays the capacity of queue in thread pool. Default value is 100k.
-r <heap> Displays the heap size (in MB) for database dump process. This option is set depending upon the available RAM.
-F Forces the db-list tool to execute on the AdminCLI pod.

Example

Output similar to the following screenshots appear when you run the db-list tool as a root user with no arguments:

The tool asks for a confirmation before proceeding with its task.

The tool also prints progress in terms of the number of records processed after every 30 seconds.

db-stats

Nokia
Smart Plan Suite
9YZ-09126-MT02-REZZA
Nokia

Description

This command displays Aerospike database statistics, including the number of records, memory usage, disk usage, local cluster data migration, and cross site data replication.

There is a summary view that would be a typical starting point. There are also more verbose views available for drilling further into the per-node statistics.

This tool can be executed on the AdminCLI pod at any time.

Syntax

db-stats -s <set> [-i] [-c] [-o <dir/file>]
db-stats -v <stat_type> [-s <set>] [-o <dir/file>]
db-stats -l [-o <dir/file>]
Code Description
No arguments Displays usage/help information.
-h Displays usage/help information.
-s <set> Specifies the set (or table) to display, or all to display statistics for all sets.
-i Include a count of total Inactive records (tombstoned).
-c Configuration sets. The output will also include the site/system configuration data sets. This option can be used only with -s all and cannot be used with verbose mode. The results will be different depending on whether it is used on an ME or SM.
-l Lists Session Counts. The operation may take a while to complete.
-o <dir/file> Specifies the output directory and filename to append the DB stats output. This is written in append mode to enable a periodically-scheduled running of this command (e.g. daily) to form a historical view. For the current directory, use ./<file>
-v <stat_type>

Verbose mode for a given stat type, showing stats for each node in the DB cluster.

Note: For large DB clusters, the verbose output may be quite long.

Stat type may be:
  • records: Record counts. When this stat type is used, the -s <set> is also required.
  • memory: Memory and disk usage.
  • migrate: Local cluster data migration.
  • repl: Cross site data replication.
  • all: All of the above stat types, for -s all

Example Output

The following explains the output of db-stats:
  • Record count summary: Every record appears in the system two times (replication factor is two). The total unique record counts shown take this into account, and divides the total record counts by the replication factor to display a total unique record count.

  • Namespace: The record count summary has column headings for the namespace of the various data sets.

    Namespaces have the following meaning:
    • spspd<id>: This namespace contains the SPS ME partitioned data that is replicated to one other SPS ME site in the network. Each namespace is replicated to a different SPS site.
    • spsglobal: Data in this namespace is replicated to all other SPS MEs in the network. This namespace includes routing/mapping data for locating the Home SPS ME for any given record.
    • spslocal: Data in this namespace is configured locally on this SPS and is not replicated to any other SPS sites.
    • sps: Data in this namespace is configured on SM and pushed to SPS ME. It is not replicated to any other SPS sites.
  • Unknown: If a database node does not respond to the statistics query, its status is displayed as Unknown. When this happens, the unique record count totals are only approximate.
  • Grp: DB nodes are grouped into two groups, with one copy of each record existing in Group 1 and the other copy in Group 2.
  • Data migration: When a database node cluster changes (e.g. a DB node fails, or a DB node recovers, or a DB node is grown into the system), the database may initiate automatic migration of replicated partitions amongst the DB nodes in this local system to maintain the replication factor and the balance across nodes. During this migration period, the unique record count totals are only approximate and are likely underestimated.
  • Data migration, Xmit: Total number of partitions pending to be sent out to others from this node. Will be 0 in a normal steady state.
  • Data migration, Rcv: Total number of partitions being received from other nodes at this moment. Will be 0 in a normal steady state.
  • Total Unique Records: The number of unique records, which in a normal system in steady state, is equal to the total records divided by the replication factor. (For example, if there are 1,000 total records and the replication factor is 2, then the actual number of unique records is 500, with there being 2 copies of each record).
  • Active Records: The number of unique active records. Active records are the only ones that are visible and accessible to provisioning and application processing. (Active records are those that have not been recently deleted and therefore do not have any temporary tombstone records remaining in the database).
  • Inactive Records: The number of unique inactive records. These are records which have been deleted but for which a tombstone remains in the system.

  • Cross site data replication: This is the replication of data across SPS systems in the operator network. Various metrics are reported for this replication, including:

    System metrics:
    • Digest log records: Number of records logged into digest log.
    • Digest log free %: Percentage of the digest log free and available for use.
    • Digest log relogged: Number of records relogged into the digest log due to temporary issues when attempting to ship.
    Metrics per remote data center:
    • State of the remote DC: Values can include UP, DOWN, INACTIVE, or WINDOW_SHIP.
    • In flight: Number of records that are in flight (which have been shipped but for which a response from the remote DC has not yet been received).
    • Ship ok (K): Number of records that have been successfully shipped, in thousands.
    • Ship err dest: Number of errors from the remote destination cluster(s) while shipping records for this DC. Errors include out-of-space, key-busy, etc.
    • Ship err src: Number of client layer errors while shipping records for this DC. Errors include timeout, bad network fd, etc.
    • Ship (MB): Number of Megabytes successfully shipped.
    • Time lag: Time lag for this specific DC. The timelag represents the time (in seconds) it took the latest successfully shipped record from the moment it was first written at the source until it was successfully shipped to the destination cluster. Another way of saying this is the difference between the current time and the times stamp of the record which was last successfully shipped (each record written at the source is time stamped as it gets written into the replication digestlog). When having multiple destination DCs, this represents the maximum time lag across all those remote DCs. Under normal operations, though, the timelag for each DC will be the same, given that the DB ships records in lock-step. The timelag at each DC would be different when a DC is down or in the CLUSTER_WINDOW_ SHIP state.
    • Avg latency: Moving average latency in milliseconds to ship a record to remote SPS sites.

Example: Normal default db-stats (summary mode)

This example shows the default summary view of the DB statistics. If any stats look unusual, another db-stats command can be run in verbose mode for the given stats type.
db-stats -s all
DB CLUSTER INFO
-------------------------
Total DB nodes: 4
DB nodes responding: 4
ACTIVE RECORDS SUMMARY
----------------------

Example: Verbose mode for “records” stat type, for all sets

This example shows a verbose view of the total records on each DB node. The record counts are for all data sets in the “spsglobal” namespace and the various “spspd” namespaces.
Note: db-stats -v records -s all -c is not supported by the db-stats tool where the ‘c’ option is used to list local configuration data records.
db-stats -v records -s all
DB CLUSTER INFO
-------------------------
Total DB nodes: 4
DB nodes responding: 4
ACTIVE RECORDS SUMMARY FOR SET: all
Grp Node Total spsglobal spsundologs spspd(all)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
2 135.121.42.126 11,841,714 8,736,179 0 3,105,535
1 135.121.42.119 12,301,359 9,072,938 0 3,228,421
1 135.121.42.120 12,190,304 8,992,264 0 3,198,040
2 135.121.42.121 12,649,949 9,329,023 0 3,320,926
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total 48,983,326 36,130,404 0 12,852,922
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This example shows a verbose view of the total records on each DB node. The record counts are for one specific data set in the “spspd” namespaces. There can be from 1 to 5 of the spspd namespaces, depending on the network deployment configuration.
db-stats -v records -s clubDynamic

Example: Verbose mode for “memory” stat type

This example shows a verbose view of memory and disk usage for each of the DB nodes in the local cluster.
db-stats -v memory

-------------------------
Total DB nodes: 4
DB nodes responding: 4

Free Mem
(%) Disk(MB) Disk (%)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
1 135.121.42.119 dsclocal 21,845 99 131,070
99

99
1 135.121.42.119 spspd102 21,845 99 131,070
99

99

99
1 135.121.42.119 dscglobal 21,845 95 131,070
98

This example shows a verbose view of local cluster data migration for each of the DB nodes.
db-stats -v migrate

-------------------------
Total DB nodes: 4
DB nodes responding: 3
Not responding IP:
135.121.42.126

----------------------------

----------------------------------------

1 135.121.42.120 2 0
2 135.121.42.121 3 2
135.121.42.126 Unknown Unknown

Example: Summary db-stats with one or more DB nodes not responding

db-stats -s all -i
